name: AI & the Brain: As We Embrace AI, Let’s Not Forget Our Minds

image.alt_text: AI & the Brain: As We Embrace AI, Let’s Not Forget Our Minds

contributors.name: Olivia Joseph
contributors.title: Master’s Student in Computation & Cognition
contributors.details: Olivia Joseph is a Master’s student studying Computation and Cognition at MIT, where she also completed her undergraduate degree in Computer Science & Brain and Cognitive Sciences. She is interested in perceptual development and works as a researcher in the Sinha Lab, investigating both the computational principles and biological processes of brain plasticity. As an undergraduate, Olivia also concentrated in Education to better understand learning and development from both cognitive and classroom-based perspectives. She has worked in local public school classrooms and has been a tutor for grade school students for the past six years. Olivia is also a member of MIT’s women’s varsity basketball team.

contributors.name: Sanjay Sarma
contributors.title: Professor of Mechanical Engineering
contributors.details: Sanjay Sarma, distinguished leader in academia and business, is professor of mechanical engineering at MIT. Until May 2025, he was CEO, President, and Dean of the Asia School of Business. Sarma received his PhD from UC Berkeley, his Masters from CMU and his Bachelors from IIT. His expertise includes RFID, sensors, manufacturing, autonomy, AI, sustainability and innovation. In addition to his academic achievements, Sarma has been highly influential in education, helping establish Singapore University of Technology and Design, serving as the first Director of Digital Learning at MIT and as the Vice President for Open learning at MIT. His initiatives include MIT Open Learning, MicroMasters, the Jameel World Education Lab, the MIT Integrated Learning Initiative and MIT xPro.

contributors.name: Izzat Jarudi
contributors.title: Co-Founder & CEO
contributors.details: Izzat Jarudi’s journey took him from Lebanon to the US, and from near dropout to MIT Phi Beta Kappa in Brain & Cognitive Sciences and Yale PhD in Cognitive and Social Psychology. He has worked in AI-driven companies such as Cambridge Mobile Telematics, where he was a manager for large product and data science teams supporting millions of users and using cutting-edge machine learning techniques. As Co-Founder and CEO of Edifii, Dr. Jarudi is developing an AI and Neuroscience-based mentor for students, counselors, and parents. Edifii was one of a dozen companies chosen nationally by the US Department of Education for its Small Business Innovation Research grant in 2024 and was a member of the inaugural cohort of Techstars Economic Mobility program in 2023.

contributors.name: Chris Gabrieli
contributors.title: Chairman
contributors.details: Chris Gabrieli has chaired the Massachusetts Board of Higher Education since 2015, making him the longest-serving state board chair in the U.S. and the only one appointed by both a Democratic and Republican Governor. He has led key policy initiatives, including the Massachusetts Early College Initiative, which serves nearly 10,000 students and boosts college success rates for historically underserved students. A Lecturer at Harvard’s Graduate School of Education for over a decade, he teaches on education policy change and on innovations in blending K-12, college, and careers. Over 25 years, he has co-founded education nonprofits, including Empower Schools. He has held appointments from three Massachusetts Governors and the Mayor of Boston and served on several university boards.

events.name: Code Switch: Defending Black EdTech amid AI Crackdowns
Pedagogy, Politics, & Place: Video PD for a Polarized Age

image.alt_text: Pedagogy, Politics, & Place: Video PD for a Polarized Age

description:
Across homes, offices, and classrooms, AI is becoming ubiquitous—mapping our routes, writing our code, even dreaming up art in seconds. What once sounded like science fiction is now silently transforming our daily existence. And yet, amid this great digital leap forward, a quieter, more fragile system is at stake: the human brain.
We are perched at a precipice in history. As AI systems grow in power and presence, we must ask a question too few dare to voice: What is this doing to us - our capacity to explore, to learn, to reason, and to create? The machines are learning. But are we forgetting?
long_description:
Across homes, offices, and classrooms, AI is becoming ubiquitous—mapping our routes, writing our code, even dreaming up art in seconds. What once sounded like science fiction is now silently transforming our daily existence. And yet, amid this great digital leap forward, a quieter, more fragile system is at stake: the human brain.
We are perched at a precipice in history. As AI systems grow in power and presence, we must ask a question too few dare to voice: What is this doing to us - our capacity to explore, to learn, to reason, and to create? The machines are learning. But are we forgetting?
sort: AI & THE BRAIN: AS WE EMBRACE AI, LET?S NOT FORGET OUR MINDS

name: Who’s Funding the Future—and Who’s Getting Left Out

contributors.name: Jose Pinero
contributors.title: Executive Director
contributors.details: José Piñero is the Executive Director of SomosVC, where he leads efforts to expand opportunity and representation for Latino/as and allies in venture capital. With more than 20 years of experience in business leadership, nonprofit governance, and community empowerment, José guides SomosVC’s strategy to strengthen the VC talent pipeline, elevate emerging fund managers, and grow the organization’s impact through scalable programs, partnerships, and data-driven thought leadership. José has held senior leadership roles at Microsoft and Procter & Gamble and has played key governance roles across the nonprofit sector, including serving as Board Chair of Hopelink, where he co-led a multi-million-dollar capital campaign. Nationally recognized as the “Top Coach for Latinos,” he is the creator of the Latino Career Test™ and a longtime advocate for Latino/a leadership and economic mobility across corporate, philanthropic, and entrepreneurial ecosystems.

contributors.name: Jay Lundy
contributors.title: Managing Director
contributors.details: Jay Lundy is the managing director of NAACP Capital, NAACP’s new venture capital fund leveraging innovation to close systemic gaps in healthcare, economic access, education, and climate equity for communities of color. With a $200 million fund underway, Jay pioneers investment in both founders and fund managers building scalable, high-impact solutions for a more inclusive economy. During the pandemic, he led the nationally recognized Secure Paycheck Protection Program, disbursing loans that helped over 2,500 small Black and Brown- owned businesses rebuild trust with financial institutions. Jay leverages his private sector leadership to deliver not just products but also dignity, to make the venture ecosystem more equitable.

contributors.name: Govind Shivkumar
contributors.title: Director, Investments
contributors.details: Govind Shivkumar, a Director at Omidyar Network, oversees for-profit investments in late-stage AI and emerging tech companies and funds. He also stewards portfolios and grants in Open-Source Technologies, Data Governance and Public interest AI initiatives. Some of his recent investments / portfolio include Anthropic, EleutherAI, Stanford HAI, Skydeck VC Fund, and Humane Intelligence.

contributors.name: Lili Gangas
contributors.title: Chief Technology Community Officer
contributors.details: Lili Gangas is the Chief Technology Community Officer at the Kapor Foundation, an operating foundation at the intersection of technology and racial justice, providing research and thought leadership, operating programs, supporting strategic partnerships and investments to increase diversity across the tech ecosystem--from K-12 education through entrepreneurship and venture capital. She co-leads the Kapor Center’s Equitable Tech Policy Initiative with a focus on inclusive technology policy with special interests in closing digital divide, scaling new tech workforce models, advocating for responsible emerging technology as well as providing foundational support across civic engagement issues and tech enablement of civic organizations.

description: While billions flow into tech, too little reaches the people building for equity, justice, and long-term public benefit. This session brings together leaders rethinking who gets to fund emerging tech and why—across both venture capital and philanthropy. We'll explore how to back founders closest to the problems, build alternatives to extractive tech, and redirect capital toward innovation that actually serves communities. It's time to expand who defines innovation—and who profits from it.

name: Turning Up the Heat: Climate Content That Clicks

contributors.name: Susie Jaramillo
contributors.title: CEO
contributors.details: Susie Jaramillo is an Emmy-nominated director, artist, and board director, and the co-founder and CEO of Encantos, an award-winning children’s entertainment tech company named one of Fast Company’s Most Innovative Companies. She is also the creator of Canticos, the #1 bilingual preschool brand and series, beloved by families everywhere.At Encantos, Susie builds brands with purpose, fueled by fans and brought to life through apps, books, content, and consumer products. Encantos uses a digital, direct-to-consumer model to bring properties like Canticos™, Skeletina™, Tiny Travelers™, and This is Cooler™ to families worldwide, redefining the media landscape.Susie has been widely recognized for her creative leadership and cultural impact, with features in Deadline, The Hollywood Reporter, Forbes, NPR, ABC, NBC, and CBS. She was recently named The Ad Club’s People of the Year and honored on NBCUniversal + Telemundo’s Inspiring America list.A sought-after speaker on culture, creativity, and entrepreneurship, Susie has shared her insights at events across the country. She also serves on the board of The Moth.

contributors.name: Mindy Thomas
contributors.title: Co-Founder and Chief Creative Tinkerer, Host of Wow in the World
contributors.details: Mindy Thomas is the co-creator and co-host of NPR’s Wow in the World, the #1 science podcast for kids. Through contagious curiosity and irreverent humor, she’s helped millions of families fall in love with science—often through topics like climate, sustainability, and ecosystems. As a children’s media producer and co-founder of Tinkercast, Mindy’s mission is to entertain and educate kids while inspiring awe for the planet.

contributors.name: JJ Johnson
contributors.title: Founder, Executive Producer, Director
contributors.details: J.J. Johnson is a four-time Emmy-winning executive producer, director, and writer, and the founding partner of Sinking Ship Entertainment. He has created over 17 acclaimed children’s series, including Dino Dana, Annedroids (Amazon), Endlings (Hulu), Ghostwriter (Apple TV+), Lockdown (YouTube Originals), and Jane (Apple TV+), an environmental activism show created with the Jane Goodall Institute. A bestselling author and industry thought leader, J.J. has spoken at the UN, Geena Davis Institute, and International Communication Association, and co-authored multiple academic papers. He currently serves as co-chair of the Youth Media Alliance in Canada

contributors.name: Laura Schifter
contributors.title: Senior Fellow
contributors.details: Laura Schifter is a Senior Fellow at the Aspen Institute and leads This Is Planet Ed, a national initiative focused on empowering educators, students, and parents to drive climate solutions. A former senior education staffer on Capitol Hill and lecturer at Harvard, she brings a unique blend of research, policy, and lived experience as a mother. Laura focuses on how parents can be activated as a powerful audience for climate communication and change, making her a leading voice on climate and kids.

contributors.name: Tara Palmeri
contributors.title: Journalist
contributors.details: Tara Palmeri is the host of The Tara Palmeri Show and author of The Red Letter, a hard-hitting newsletter about power, politics, and the people who shape both. One of the most feared and fearless reporters in Washington, she has spent more than 15 years covering national politics and foreign affairs. Tara was previously a White House Correspondent for ABC News, where she covered the first Trump administration, and the Chief National Correspondent for POLITICO during the Biden years. She’s also served as a political analyst for CNBC, CBS, and CNN, and began her career as a columnist for the Washington Examiner before joining the New York Post. As a foreign correspondent for POLITICO Europe, she reported across the continent on global power shifts, including Brexit. Tara has hosted multiple acclaimed podcasts, including Broken: Jeffrey Epstein and Power: The Maxwells, and previously hosted Somebody’s Gotta Win for The Ringer while writing a politics column for Puck.

contributors.name: Imran Ahmed
contributors.title: CEO
contributors.details: Imran Ahmed is the founder and CEO of the Center for Countering Digital Hate (CCDH), leading efforts to hold social media and AI companies accountable when their systems harm children and undermine our shared civic life. A recognized authority on the social and psychological impacts of digital platforms and the manipulation of our information environment, he regularly appears in the media and in documentaries and advises policymakers on common-sense safeguards that put people first.

description: Truth is harder to pin down than ever. This session explores how algorithms, AI, platform design, and evolving media ecosystems are reshaping how people understand what’s real. As trust in information sources shifts, we’ll look at how public belief is formed, how it can be influenced, and what that means for the future of shared reality. The conversation will offer practical insight into how creators, technologists, and communicators can help rebuild trust in an age of information overload. In conversation with Imran Ahmed, the session will feature a leading, award-winning journalist known for shaping national conversations on truth, media, and influence.

The conversation will offer practical insight into how creators, technologists, and communicators can help rebuild trust in an age of information overload. In conversation with Imran Ahmed, the session will feature a leading, award-winning journalist known for shaping national conversations on truth, media, and influence.

name: Technology Convergence: Winning the Exponential Upswing

contributors.name: Connie Kuang
contributors.title: Technology Convergence Initiative Lead
contributors.details:
Connie leads the Technology Convergence Initiative at the World Economic Forum. Her publications at the Forum have spanned the Metaverse, Inclusive AI, and AI Transformation of Industries, shaping its thought leadership on emerging technologies and their cross-sector implications. 

Previously, she served as Director of Marketing at Felix & Paul Studios, where she received a Primetime Emmy for contributions to Space Explorers: The ISS Experience. She brings a rare blend of strategic foresight, creative execution, and tech fluency, grounded in years of operating experience building content, products, and campaigns for audiences across immersive, consumer, and e-commerce platforms.

contributors.name: Kary Bheemaiah
contributors.title: Chief Tech & Innovation Officer- Capgemini Invent I Exec Fellow – World Economic Forum
contributors.details: Kary leads emerging tech initiatives, establishing Capgemini’s Quantum Lab, Engineering Biology accelerator, AIxRobotics Lab, and Edge AI practice. With expertise in strategic planning, execution (from funding to autonomy), and managing major innovation programs, Kary offers pragmatic solutions for firms’ challenges and market positioning. He is the lead author of the World Economic Forum’s Technological Convergence report and author of the book, The Blockchain Alternative. His insights appear in MIT Tech Review, WIRED, Harvard Business Review, and more. Formerly an Associate Research Scientist at Cambridge, Senior Fellow at Ecole des Ponts, and 2 X TEDx speaker. In a previous life, Kary served in the French Foreign Legion, earning the Cross of Valor for combat operations in Afghanistan.

description: Every industrial revolution started with mashups. Today, advanced digital, biological, and physical technologies are creating their S-Curves together, unleashing a burst of convergence that generates value none could release alone, a dynamic mapped by the World Economic Forum's Technology Convergence Report. In this hands-on session, executives and founders will work through a diagnostic framework to map the intricacies of today's technology landscape, stress-test where their next major bet sits within the convergence wave, and walk away with a practical lens they can apply immediately.

contributors.name: Cecilia Waismann
contributors.title: Vice President
contributors.details: VP MindCET EdTech Innovation Centre, brings together educators, researchers, students, and entrepreneurs to accelerate innovation in education. Expert on the impact of cutting-edge tech and internet culture on how new generations learn and engage with education. PhD in Psychology from the Institute of Psychiatry, University of London, MSc in Social Psychology LSE. Career spans mental health, education, and policy across England, Spain, Brazil, and Israel, with leadership roles principal, researcher, policy advisor. Worked with the European Community, Maudsley Hospital, Andalusia Health Services, Tel Aviv University, and the Diaspora Museum. An internationally recognized speaker, she has published extensively on education, technology, and the evolving ways students learn in the digital age.

contributors.name: Avi Warshavsky
contributors.title: CEO
contributors.details: Avi Warshavsky MindCET CEO & Founder of MindCET, a global hub driving innovation, on Board of Directors of the Center for Educational Technology, held senior leadership positions Head of Humanities and Social Studies and Director of eBook initiatives, pioneering new models for digital learning in Israel’s education system. Acclaimed thought leader, pioneered global initiatives that have shaped today’s EdTech landscape. Founded the Global EdTech Startup Awards (GESAwards) in 2014, co-founded the UK–Israel EdTech Task Force, and currently chairs the board of many EdTech companies such as Connecteam, Plethora, Jotit, CodeMonkey, and is a Managing Partner at MindCET Capital. International voice a frequent speaker at leading EdTech forums across North and South America, Europe, Asia, and Africa

name: Game On: Reimagining Career Exploration Through Play

contributors.name: Benedetta Naglieri
contributors.title: Education Director
contributors.details: Benedetta Naglieri is Learning Undefeated’s Director of Education, leading dynamic laboratory and deep-impact programs that inspire middle and high school students to explore and excel in STEM. She earned her Ph.D. in molecular biology from Columbia University and completed postdoctoral research at the National Institutes of Health, where she studied gene regulation. Her passion for informal science education was sparked while volunteering as a science instructor, leading her to STEM educator roles at the Children’s Science Center (Herndon, Virginia) and the Liberty Science Center (Jersey City, NJ) before joining Learning Undefeated. In her free time, she enjoys running and is a dedicated fan of classic movies.

contributors.name: Brian Gaines
contributors.title: CEO
contributors.details: Brian Gaines has served as CEO of Learning Undefeated since 2012, advancing its mission and vision. An entrepreneurial leader at the intersection of the for-profit and nonprofit sectors, he has led community-focused and social change organizations including the Washington Commanders Foundation, Peer Forward (formerly College Summit), and KaBOOM! Earlier in his career, Brian opened the first Ben & Jerry’s retail chain in the Bay Area and served as Founding Executive Director of Joshua Venture, a national philanthropy fund backing emerging nonprofit leaders.

contributors.name: Asha Varghese
contributors.title: President
contributors.details: Asha Varghese is the President of the Caterpillar Foundation. In her role, she leads Caterpillar Inc.’s global CSR strategy to build resilient communities by investing in the skills people need for the workforce and the natural and vital infrastructure they depend on. Prior to Caterpillar, Asha spent 15 years at GE, where she held various leadership roles, including at the GE Foundation. She holds a bachelor’s degree in computer engineering and computer science from the University of Louisville and an MBA from Northwestern University’s Kellogg School of Management. She is a 2018 graduate of the Presidential Leadership Scholars Program, a joint initiative of the presidential centers of George W. Bush, Bill Clinton, George H.W. Bush, and Lyndon B. Johnson. She resides in Washington, D.C.

contributors.name: Jeremy Weir
contributors.title: Teacher
contributors.details: Jeremy Weir is in his fifth year as the Engineering teacher at Seguin High School. Throughout his time at Seguin, he has focused on strengthening the engineering program and building connections with industry professionals to expand opportunities for his students. He emphasizes bridging classroom learning with real-world experiences through hands-on projects and certifi cation programs that prepare students for success beyond high school.

description: Manufacturing is high-tech, high-paying, and full of opportunity—yet this vital industry still ranks last among teens’ career choices. By blending game-based learning, Dimensions of Success, and authentic career experiences shaped by SMEs and teachers, a futuristic learning pod is reshaping how students view advanced manufacturing. After one semester, students are 75% more likely to consider careers in the field, and 63% want further learning. Discover how a global industry leader, a nonprofit, and educators are sparking new enthusiasm and transforming perceptions of technical careers.

contributors.details: In addition to Chair of the National Fitness Foundation, Dr. Judith Brown Clarke is the Vice President for Equity & Inclusion and Chief Health Equity Officer for Stony Brook University and Health System. She reports directly to the University President and sits on the university’s senior leadership teams, including the President’s Cabinet, University Council, Vice Presidents Council and Campus Climate. Clarke has experienced great athletic success, she is a 4-time national collegiate champion, 12-time Big Ten Champion, 3-time Pan American Games gold medalist, 1984 Olympic Silver Medalist, and 1987 Sports Illustrated Woman of the Year.

contributors.name: Steve Amos
contributors.title: CEO
contributors.details:
Steve is a social entrepreneur with 40+ years in technology, US/Global marketing, advertising, education, healthcare, and nonprofits. Founder/CEO of the nonprofit HealthCode, whose mission is to empower people to live healthier, happier lives free from preventable chronic disease. 

Earned an M.B.A. from Wake Forest University, a BA from Florida State University, graduate studies in London and in Oceanography at the University of Guam, and serves as a Texas A&M University Center for Public Health and Aging Affiliate.

description:
Our students, educators, schools, and nation face a health crisis—our diets and inactivity are killing us. Over 70% of youth are unfit for military service. 71% of girls, 58% of boys don’t meet activity guidelines. By 2030, Americans will be half as active as in 1965. 
This Meet Up unites cross-sector changemakers ready for a Moon Shot: bold, collaborative action to improve the health of students and educators.

image.alt_text: American Exchange Project: Experiential Civics in Action

contributors.name: David McCullough III
contributors.title: Co-Founder & CEO
contributors.details: David McCullough III is the cofounder and CEO of the American Exchange Project, a first-of-its-kind domestic intercultural exchange program. McCullough was inspired to launch the project after he spent two months traveling 7,100 miles across the country in 2016. In collaboration with PBS NewsHour Economic Correspondent Paul Solman and the late Harvard Business School Professor Robert Glauber, McCullough founded the American Exchange Project in 2019 and has since sent more than 1,000 students to nearly 40 states to create a more connected America. McCullough holds a BA in American Studies from Yale and an MPhil in Economic and Social History from the University of Cambridge. In 2022, he was named to Forbes’s 30 Under 30 list in Education.

description: Picture this: Students from 8 different towns across the U.S. are watching the sun set in L.A. Among them is a line-dancing photographer from Texas, an aspiring chef from south L.A., and an avid reader becoming a real-life main character. Through the American Exchange Project, a free domestic exchange program, students get a greater understanding of themselves, their new friends, and the country we all share. In this solo talk, David McCullough III explores how domestic exchanges are the interactive civics lesson students need at this crucial time in American history.

name: Empowering Students for the Jobs of Tomorrow

contributors.name: Kristi Kirk
contributors.title: President & CEO
contributors.details:
Dr. Kristi Kirk was appointed the 10th President and CEO of Concordia University Texas in November 2024, becoming the first woman to lead the institution in its 100-year history. With more than 30 years of experience in higher education, she has dedicated her career to expanding access and opportunity, especially for underserved communities in Central Texas.

Dr. Kirk began her Concordia journey in 1993 as an admissions office manager. Over the decades, she rose through the ranks, eventually becoming Provost and Executive Vice President, a role she held for nine years before assuming the presidency. 

Her story, from student worker to president, reflects a deep, enduring commitment to the higher education industry and private, Christ-centered institutions.

long_description: The SXSW Community Service Awards celebrate leaders and non-profit organizations from Austin and around the world who work tirelessly to improve the standing of the specific groups and causes that they serve.Taylor McGraw is a journalist and educator dedicated to giving young people the tools to tell their own stories. Prior to co-founding The Bell in 2017, he spent five years teaching and coaching in New York City schools, where he recognized that the voices most impacted by education policy were the ones least involved in shaping it.Under his leadership, The Bell has grown from a podcast project into a nationally recognized leader in youth-led journalism. The organization’s student reporting has shifted from the classroom to the halls of power: its coverage of school segregation and inequity has been cited in citywide policy discussions and featured on national airwaves. The Bell’s student reporters have twice been named finalists for the National Awards for Education Reporting, competing against professional newsrooms of all sizes.Beyond producing impactful youth-led storytelling, Taylor is a driving force for systemic change in journalism education. In 2022, he spearheaded the formation of the NYC Youth Journalism Coalition, a collective effort to strengthen the journalism career pipeline. Through the Coalition's ""Journalism for All"" initiative, The Bell and partners are actively expanding journalism programs to dozens of schools that historically lacked them, democratizing access to the field for thousands of students.Now based in Jackson, Mississippi, Taylor is scaling The Bell's work through the Jackson Youth Newsroom, a program focused on building a new generation of civic-minded journalists in the Deep South.Taylor holds an MFA in Creative Writing from The New School, an MA in Teaching from Relay GSE, and a BA in Public Policy Leadership from the University of Mississippi. His love for journalism began at his own high school newspaper in Oxford, Mississippi, and he remains committed to ensuring that every student has a platform to speak truth to power.
sort: SXSW COMMUNITY SERVICE AWARDS RECOGNITION: THE BELL

description: We are in the worst reading crisis in American history, a reflection of an education standard that has stagnated for almost half a century, yet the system is now being transformed through the Science of Reading. Author James Patterson takes us on a journey with several elementary schools throughout Florida that have implemented curriculum based on the Science of Reading provided by the UFLI Foundations program led by Dr. Holly Lane.  This new system is rebooting the entire way we teach reading to our kids, and these are the emotional stories from the front lines of The Reading Reboot.

name: The Learning Geeks: How to Think When Machines Think Faster

contributors.name: Dana Koch
contributors.title: Learning Scientist
contributors.details: With a forty year career in professional education, Dana has used his academic training in the learning sciences to create effective learning experiences that factor in the neuroscience of learning. He led the Institute for the Learning Sciences a team of researchers that supported the creation of effective evidence-based learning interventions. He has authored and co-authored several articles and book chapters.

contributors.name: Tessa Forshaw
contributors.title: Co-Founder & Researcher, Next Level Lab
contributors.details: Tessa Forshaw, PhD, is a cognitive scientist and co-founder of the Next Level Lab at Harvard University, where she studies the cognition of learning and working through design-based research practices. She teaches design thinking, creativity, and innovation at the Harvard Innovation Lab and Harvard University DCE, and served on the Teaching Faculty at Stanford's d.school for several years. Previously, Tessa has worked as a Design Fellow at IDEO's CoLab and in Accenture's Strategy, Insight, and Innovation team. Tessa is the co-author of Innovation-ish, an accessible and cognitive science-informed book on how real people, in the real world, can engage in creative problem solving.

contributors.name: Bob Gerard
contributors.title: Director, Learning Ingenuity
contributors.details: Bob Gerard is a thirty-year-plus learning industry veteran who has held pretty much every role imaginable in the learning space at one time or another. Currently, Bob leads the Learning Ingenuity team within Accenture’s HR organization, which is essentially “research and development for how Accenture people learn better.” Bob is also the co-host of The Learning Geeks podcast, a program that reaches thousands of learning professionals around the world. He lives in Long Beach, California with his wife Sherri, a cat, and a pretty cool home arcade.

contributors.name: Jake Gittleson
contributors.title: Learning Lab Leader
contributors.details: Jake is a learning design and innovation leader with over 18 years of experience in the L&D profession. As the co-founder and leader of McKinsey’s Research and Innovation Learning Lab, Jake oversees a team specializing in experimentation, research, learning science, apprenticeship, and emerging trends. He is a passionate people developer dedicated to building top-tier experts who design cutting-edge upskilling initiatives that drive impact across the Firm. Jake is also a co-host and producer of an industry-leading podcast, The Learning Geeks. He has written various articles for McKinsey.com and has served as a speaker, conference committee member, and contributor for various industry institutions, including the Association for Talent Development (ATD) and The Learning Forum.

description: AI helps us work faster than ever—but are we sacrificing how we develop? In this live podcast, we discuss why metacognition—how we think, feel, and learn—is the human advantage when partnering with AI in our work. We’ll unpack how intentional thinking helps people decide when to offload to AI, when to lean in, and how to grow through the process. Expect practical insights, geeky discussions, and evidence-based strategies you can immediately apply to monitor, evaluate, and optimize your learning and working as AI increasingly influences our lives.

name: The Climate Paradox of AI Education

contributors.name: Angel Hsu
contributors.title: Associate Professor & Founding Director
contributors.details: Dr. Angel Hsu is an Associate Professor of Public Policy and the Environment at UNC-Chapel Hill and the founder and director of the Data-Driven EnviroLab. Her research explores the intersection of science and policy and the use of data-driven approaches, including AI, to advance understanding and action on environmental sustainability, particularly in the areas of climate change, energy, urbanization, and air quality. She leads the CLAIM Center (Center for Climate Leadership and AI-driven Integrity in Mitigation), a new initiative focused on examining how generative AI tools like large language models are shaping—and complicating—the credibility, communication, and governance of climate action.

contributors.name: Vijay Gadepally
contributors.title: Senior Scientist & Chief Technology Officer
contributors.details: Vijay Gadepally is a Senior Scientist and Principal Investigator at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) Lincoln Laboratory. At Lincoln Laboratory, Vijay leads the research efforts of the Lincoln Laboratory Supercomputing Center. His research interests include high-performance computing, AI, high-performance databases and environmentally-friendly computing. Vijay is also the CTO of Radium Cloud – a company focused on providing high-performance cloud computing for AI workloads – and advises multiple early-stage venture-backed startups.Vijay’s research in high-performance computing, artificial intelligence and environmentally-friendly computing has been featured in numerous articles in the popular press and has received numerous scholarly awards at various conferences.

contributors.name: Betsy Beck
contributors.title: Director, Energy Markets - Americas
contributors.details: Betsy Beck serves as Director of Energy Markets at Microsoft, bringing deep expertise in energy policy and market development to support the company's expanding AI and cloud infrastructure needs. Beck previously spent almost three years in Global Energy Markets and Policy at Google. Her career includes leadership roles at Enel Green Power North America as Director of Regulatory Affairs, overseeing corporate strategy across major power markets, including the Electric Reliability Council of Texas (ERCOT), Southwest Power Pool (SPP), and others. She also held positions at the American Wind Energy Association (AWEA) with extensive Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) experience. Betsy holds a Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Materials Science, from the University of Pennsylvania.

contributors.name: Rebecca (Becky) Boyles
contributors.title: Deputy Director, RENCI; Professor of the Practice, Data Science & Society
contributors.details: Rebecca Boyles (Becky) is the Deputy Director of Renaissance Computing Institute (RENCI), a collaborative research institute at UNC Chapel Hill that develops and deploys data science cyberinfrastructure that helps researchers use data to drive discoveries, innovate, make informed decisions, and spur economic development, where she leads the Research Division. Becky is a Principal Investigator for the NHLBI BioData Catalyst Coordinating Center, overseeing the FAIR data framework for a cross-cloud cyberinfrastructure that integrates genomics workflows, community tools, and secure workspaces. Previously, she was the Founding Director of RTI International’s Center for Data Modernization Solutions and a data scientist at the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences (NIEHS).

description: As AI transforms climate education with personalized learning and interactive simulations, we face an uncomfortable truth: the data centers powering these solutions are driving massive energy consumption that threatens to undermine our climate goals. With data center electricity use projected to double by 2030, how do we justify using energy-intensive AI to teach climate solutions? We'll examine real trade-offs, share concrete solutions, and propose a path toward AI-powered climate education that helps rather than harms our environmental future.
long_description: As AI transforms climate education with personalized learning and interactive simulations, we face an uncomfortable truth: the data centers powering these solutions are driving massive energy consumption that threatens to undermine our climate goals. With data center electricity use projected to double by 2030, how do we justify using energy-intensive AI to teach climate solutions? We'll examine real trade-offs, share concrete solutions, and propose a path toward AI-powered climate education that helps rather than harms our environmental future.

name: Mentor Session: Emily Gupton (SKG)

contributors.name: Emily Gupton
contributors.title: Chief Technology Officer
contributors.details:
Emily Gupton is a forward-thinking technology executive with a multidisciplinary background and a passion for driving meaningful innovation. As Chief Technology Officer at SKG in Austin, Texas, she oversees the company’s entire technology ecosystem, including hardware, software, cybersecurity, and AI implementation, aligning digital strategy with business growth in one of the country’s fastest-growing MillerKnoll dealerships.

Emily also serves as Chief Operations Officer at FOLIO, a SaaS platform she helped build and launch within SKG’s family of companies. Her leadership helped take FOLIO from concept to operational reality, offering scalable tech solutions for the commercial furniture industry. Emily’s career journey reflects her adaptability and vision, having made three major professional pivots, from radiology to commercial construction to executive leadership in tech, each marked by her ability to lead high-performing teams across industries and disciplines.

Emily is deeply engaged in the Austin community. She serves as Board President of Austin Women in Technology, a Board Member for Workforce Solutions Capital Area, an Advisory Board Member for Truist Bank, and Events Co-Chair for the Austin AI Alliance. Her impact has also been recognized through multiple honors, including being named an Austin Woman Magazine Changemaker (2024) and a Women in Business Awards Nominee by the Austin Business Journal (2023, 2025). These roles and accolades reflect her commitment to advancing workforce development, innovation, and gender equity in tech.

She holds dual Bachelor of Science degrees in Neuroscience and Business from the University of Texas at Dallas, an MBA from Texas Woman’s University, and most recently completed a program in Digital Transformation at MIT. In her personal time, Emily finds energy in travel, quality time with loved ones, and training for her next triathlon, living her belief in balance, resilience, and continuous growth.

name: Featured Session: Strategy in the Times of Chaos: Imagining Futures of Education

contributors.name: Marina Gorbis
contributors.title: Exec Director
contributors.details: Marina Gorbis, Executive Director of the Institute for the Future, has brought a foresight and futures perspective to hundreds of organizations in business, education, government, philanthropy, and civic society. Marina’s current research focuses on transformations in the world of work and new forms of value creation. Marina's book, The Nature of the Future: Dispatches from the Socialstructed World, explores many of these themes and draws connections between the changes in our technology infrastructure and our organizational landscape, from education to governance and health.

contributors.name: Maisha T. Winn
contributors.title: Professor
contributors.details: Maisha T. Winn is the Excellence in Learning Graduate School of Education Professor and Faculty Director of the Stanford Accelerator for Learning's Equity in Learning Initiative. She is the Principal Investigator for the Futuring for Equity Lab. Her scholarship examines how non-dominant youth and communities have developed literate trajectories across a range of historical and contemporary settings within and outside formal schooling. She seeks to understand how communities that have been depicted as under resourced create practices, processes, and institutions of their own—and what we can learn from those examples to build more just, more collaborative, and more equitable futures. An ethnographer by training, Dr. Winn also engages in historical research focused on social movements in education.

description: Daily, we wake to the unimaginable becoming reality: the highest temperatures in recorded history, technology acquiring human-like communication capabilities, realignment of global alliances and ideologies. Such times of upheaval are opportunities to reinvent the institutions, ways of thinking, and modes of doing. Sociologist John Fabian Witt said, these are “occasions in which people remake the world.” In this conversation, experts with decades of experience in future-facing strategies, will share foresight techniques for imagining radically different futures and detecting signals of reinvention and scholarship on how communities depicted as under-resourced create practices and institutions of their own—as examples for building more just and equitable futures.

name: Hidden Brilliance Revealed: Reimagining Leadership in a Fragmented World

contributors.name: Joe Pardavila
contributors.title: Director Of Podcast
contributors.details: Podcaster | Author of Good Listen | Where pop culture meets business | Proud Weiner Dog Dad

contributors.name: Tony Martignetti
contributors.title: Chief Illumination Officer
contributors.details:
Tony Martignetti is a leadership and workplace culture advisor and change catalyst who helps leaders and teams navigate complexity without losing themselves in the process. With over 30 years of experience across high-tech and life sciences, Tony has worked in organizations where innovation, pressure, and uncertainty collide. Along the way, he discovered a truth that now defines his work: brilliance doesn’t disappear in organizations; it goes dormant when people are asked to fragment themselves to perform.
Through his company, Inspired Purpose Partners, Tony designs transformational experiences that unlock what he calls multidimensional leadership: the ability to integrate purpose, presence, creativity, and connection while making a meaningful impact. His work helps leaders gain clarity, make better decisions, and lead in ways that are both human and sustainable.
Tony is the best-selling author of Climbing the Right Mountain and Campfire Lessons for Leaders, the host of The Virtual Campfire Podcast, and a sought-after global keynote speaker. He is known for creating spaces, often described as “campfires,” where people can speak honestly, think expansively, and reconnect with who they are becoming. His work blends proven leadership frameworks with storytelling, design thinking, and deep relational practice to turn insight into action.

description: Most leaders are taught to narrow themselves to fit the world. But what if innovation requires the opposite? In this intimate fireside chat, Tony Martignetti shares insights from his latest book, Illuminating Hidden Brilliance, revealing how reclaiming the sidelined parts of our identity is the key to creativity, connection, and transformative leadership. Through stories, research, and practical tools, Tony shows how multidimensional thinking becomes a catalyst and why the future belongs to leaders who bring all of themselves to the table. Attendees will learn why a multidimensional perspective is a strategic advantage, how to spot hidden brilliance in themselves and others, and how organizations can create environments where people can think and lead beyond the one-dimensional demands of modern work.

contributors.name: Ashley Neville
contributors.title: Director of Insights
contributors.details: Ashley Neville is the Director of Insights at Carta, where she turns proprietary data into compelling insights that guide founders, investors, and operators across the private markets. She leads a team responsible for 20+ annual reports and creates award-winning visualizations that challenge conventional wisdom. She also writes Data Minute, Carta’s newsletter with 25K+ subscribers and a 60%+ open rate. Prior to Carta, Ashley spent over a decade at Tableau, where she led global data literacy initiatives and helped launch the award-winning Visualize No Malaria campaign. A recognized expert in data storytelling, Ashley studied International Economics at Georgetown and is based in Seattle. When not decoding data, she’s hiking the Pacific Crest Trail with her Pomsky, Aspen.

name: Mentor Session: Brance Hudzietz (Capital Factory)

contributors.name: Brance Hudzietz
contributors.title: Director of Government Programs (DARPA Commercial Accelerator)
contributors.details: With a decade of experience at the intersection of startup, corporate, and government innovation, Brance helps high growth organizations accelerate strategic initiatives. Brance maintains a robust network of corporate, government, startup, and capital partners across the country who are key to and share a common vision of a world radically evolved via emerging technologies. Brance has led strategic government initiatives for multiple startups and played a key role in the scale up of Army Applications Lab, the US Army’s leading innovation organization. Prior to this, Brance advised Fortune 1000 organizations on how to best leverage early-stage technologies for meaningful innovation at Capital Factory, Texas’ most active venture fund. He currently serves as the Director of Government Programs at Capital Factory, where he leads the DARPA Commercial Accelerator program. Through this, he connects world-changing startups with the resources they need to rapidly accelerate time to market. His career began in academic research with a focus on autonomous helicopters, materials science, and computational mathematics.Brance’s areas of interest include no-code/low-code, bootstrapping, and the intersection of technology and art. He lives in Austin, TX, where in his spare time he enjoys hammock camping, sci-fi audiobooks, and accidentally killing houseplants.

name: Afraid of AI? In Cleveland, It’s Enabling Economic Mobility

contributors.name: Michelle Rose
contributors.title: CEO
contributors.details: Michelle Rose serves as the Chief Executive Officer of Greater Cleveland Works. In this role, she leads workforce development programming and strategy for employers and jobseekers in Cuyahoga County. Cleveland Mayor Justin Bibb appointed Michelle to lead this organization in June 2022, and she has shepherded it through the process to re-launch as a nonprofit while improving delivery of services and embarking on a new strategic direction. In this role, she also established the Built Environment Collaborative, securing $10 million to connect more Clevelanders to good jobs in the skilled trades and remove barriers to success. Prior to this role, she spent most of her career at the United States Department of Labor as a senior advisor on legislative and intergovernmental affairs.

contributors.name: Michael Rosenbaum
contributors.title: Founder & CEO
contributors.details: Mike is the Founder and CEO of Arena, which applies AI to labor markets to improve career trajectories within and across industries. Earlier in his career Mike was a John M. Olin Fellow in Law and Economics at Harvard Law School and a Teaching Fellow and Instructor in the Harvard Economics Department, and he served at the White House as an economist. His publications and research focused on the application of data to the most subjective areas of human endeavor. Mike has a JD from Harvard Law School, an MSc in Economics from the LSE, and a BA from Harvard College.

description: A tale as old as time: employers need talent but can’t see who’s job-ready, and job seekers need quality jobs but have limited visibility into what’s available and pathways to get there. We’re changing that in Cleveland by coming together around a shared vision of what works and what will drive better outcomes for everyone—especially those who’ve been systemically excluded. By leveraging AI (without sacrificing any existing jobs!), we’re transforming how we connect people to opportunity and advancing economic opportunity and mobility through a smarter, more equitable workforce infrastructure.

We’re changing that in Cleveland by coming together around a shared vision of what works and what will drive better outcomes for everyone—especially those who’ve been systemically excluded. By leveraging AI (without sacrificing any existing jobs!), we’re transforming how we connect people to opportunity and advancing economic opportunity and mobility through a smarter, more equitable workforce infrastructure.
sort: AFRAID OF AI? IN CLEVELAND, IT?S ENABLING ECONOMIC MOBILITY

name: Code Switch: Defending Black EdTech amid AI Crackdowns

contributors.name: Tiffany Green
contributors.title: CEO
contributors.details: Tiffany Green is a licensed psychotherapist and founder of Uprooted Academy™, a -tech non-profit that is using AI to democratize college access. Their AI powered platform uses neuroscience and mental health research to provide a psychologically safe process for students applying to college. She has 15 years of experience in high schools (both domestically and abroad) and colleges in a first-year counseling center and as a former adjunct professor of Psychology. She is a graduate of UCONN and Howard University. Her doctoral research focuses on the impact of an AI tool to mitigate the stress that comes with applying to college. She has been featured in Forbes for her tech innovation. Tiffany currently lives in Los Angeles and has traveled to over 80 countries.

contributors.name: Shauna Knox
contributors.title: Founder & CEO
contributors.details: Dr. Shauna Knox is a leading voice in global Black Humanities, decolonial curriculum theory, and education. Her two books, published by Routledge, are used in doctoral programs nationwide. She has served as SVP of the National Black Child Development Institute, Co-Chair of the UN Permanent Forum for People of African Descent Civil Working Group, and Board Member for Maryland Humanities. At the U.S. Department of Education, she earned a Breakthrough Award and served as Subject Matter Expert on Human Trafficking and Child Labor. She was keynote speaker at the 2023 Bergamo Conference and received an Honorable Mention from AERA for her first book, Engaging Currere Toward Decolonization: Negotiating Black Womanhood through Autobiographical Analysis.

contributors.name: Symone Campbell
contributors.title: Internal Research Fellow
contributors.details: Symone Campbell is an Internal Research Fellow at Siegel Family Endowment, where she conducts original research at the intersection of technology, equity, and learning. She brings expertise in Responsible K-12 EdTech, Public Interest Technology, and AI Ethics, with a focus on supporting underrepresented students. Driven by a mission to expand Black representation in education, Symone also teaches AI Ethics as an adjunct professor at Howard University. She holds a B.A. from Buffalo State University, an M.A. from the University at Albany, and a Ph.D. in communication, culture, and media studies from Howard.

contributors.name: Angela Romans
contributors.title: Executive Director
contributors.details: Angela N. Romans is the founding Executive Director of Innovation For Equity, a national network advancing life outcomes for Black learners and increasing Black leadership in education. With 20+ years in nonprofit and public sector leadership, she has supported organizations and senior leaders in strategy, governance, DEI, adaptive leadership, and higher ed access. A former high school math and science teacher, Angela holds degrees in biomedical engineering and education from Harvard. She is an Annie E. Casey Foundation Children and Family Fellow and Vice Chair of the National Civic League. Based in Washington, DC, she brings deep expertise in equity-focused systems change and cross-sector collaboration.

One year into new AI regulations and increasing DEI rollbacks, we’ll explore how to build for resilience – embedding protections into platforms, pedagogy, and policy. Participants will learn our scalable framework for building culturally responsive STEAM ecosystems through partnerships with higher ed, industry, and gaming partners. Shruthi has led brand and spatial design projects across various industries, from Michelin-starred chefs to fashion startups, and frequently speaks on the intersection of emotion, experience, and design.

description: What if classrooms were designed like hospitality spaces—hotels, restaurants, places of welcome, rhythm, and care? In this talk, designer-researcher Shruthi Manjula Balakrishna explores how hospitality frameworks such as arrival sequence, wayfinding, sensory design, and emotional arc can reshape the rituals and environments of learning. Drawing from design psychology and service strategy, this session offers a fresh lens for fostering trust, comfort, and connection in education.

contributors.name: Dayamudra Dennehy
contributors.title: Professor
contributors.details: Dayamudra is tenured ESL faculty at City College of San Francisco with 3 decades of global classroom teaching experience. Her current area of interest is the ethical use of Generative Artificial Intelligence in higher education. She has served as a Stanford University EPIC Fellow and founded an educational non-profit with an India-based team, launching an educational residence in south India for caste-oppressed students. She has led community projects with Guatemalan Mayan weavers and Hungarian Gypsy/Roma artists, taught in Indonesia and studied in Japan and Mexico. She holds a doctorate in Educational Leadership, focused on Equity and Social Justice, and is an ordained Buddhist, teaching meditation and yoga workshops around the world. Her name means "Gesture of Compassion".

contributors.name: Denise Maduli-Williams
contributors.title: Professor
contributors.details: Dr. Denise Maduli-Williams is a dedicated community college educator and expert in online and accessible learning. With a doctorate in Educational Leadership, her research focuses on the impact of social presence and relationships in supporting minoritized students of color. Currently teaching at San Diego Miramar College, Denise excels in developing engaging online, hybrid, and on-ground courses. She has extensive experience in AI, accessibility, and online learning, integrating these technologies to promote social-emotional wellness and equitable access. Denise is passionate about leveraging technology to create inclusive and supportive educational environments.

contributors.details: Lydia Logan leads IBM's community and university skilling initiatives that create more inclusive and effective schools and workforces. Her programs help fulfill IBM’s pledges to skill 30 million people worldwide by 2030, and to train two million learners in AI through 2026.

contributors.title: Education Engagement Lead
contributors.details: As the Education Engagement Lead at Google.org, Tequila drives New York and national social impact initiatives. A passionate advocate for excellence in education, she is committed to accelerating equitable, technology-enabled improvements in student outcomes. This work is informed by strategic grantmaking and the cultivation of systems-level partnerships.  Tequila is a respected mentor, coach, and a sought-after speaker and panelist on critical topics in education, technology, and leadership. She currently serves as Chair of the NYC Public Schools Technology Industry Commission and is an active member of the NYC Student Pathways Advisory Council. Underscoring her dedication to the city's future, she was selected as a David Rockefeller Fellow with the Partnership for New York City.

contributors.name: Kiersten Barnet
contributors.title: Executive Director
contributors.details: Kiersten Barnet is Executive Director of the New York Jobs CEO Council, where she leads a coalition of Fortune 100 CEOs from companies including JP Morgan, Google, and Citigroup, committed to hiring 100,000 low-income New Yorkers into family-sustaining jobs by 2030—and they’re already more than 50% of the way there. Prior to this, she spent 15 years at Bloomberg, where she led Gender-Equality Index, helping shape how major companies globally report on social sustainability. Kiersten also co-founded the U.S. 30% Club, a group of influential CEOs, including Warren Buffett and Larry Fink,  and sits on several nonprofit and advisory boards.

description: AI's rapid integration risks leaving entire groups—and vast talent pools—behind. In this panel, explore the awareness gaps impacting low-income communities and actionable strategies to cultivate an inclusive, future-ready workforce. Learn how collaborations between today’s leading companies, nonprofits, and colleges/universities will prepare students for AI-driven careers. Ask important questions like, “should degrees even be required?,” hear real-world examples of employer-backed training to equip students with applied skills, and discover how initiatives like these can be replicated.

contributors.name: Vanessa Smith

contributors.details: Vanessa Smith is President of ServiceNow.org, where she leads efforts to bring the power of technology to nonprofits tackling the world’s toughest challenges. A tech executive with 25+ years of experience, she joined ServiceNow in 2020 as SVP of Strategic Go-to-Market, leading Business Value, Industries, and Solution Sales. Previously, Vanessa spent 16 years at SAP in leadership roles, including Managing Director of North America SuccessFactors and Chief of Staff to CEO Bill McDermott. She serves on the Board of Fastly, Inc. and as Board Chair for Teach For America Greater Philadelphia. She holds an MBA from the University of Maryland and a B.S. from the University of Virginia.

description: When public funding becomes unpredictable, how can organizations boost efficiency without stifling innovation? This fireside chat explores how the Space Telescope Science Institute, home of the Hubble and Webb telescopes, revolutionized access to space data. The lessons, born before today’s budget pressures, offer a powerful blueprint for any organization facing resource constraints. Whether you're advancing science, education, or social impact, the message is clear: Transformation is possible, even in lean times.

name: Thrive or Survive: Why Creativity is the Key to an AI-Future

image.alt_text: Thrive or Survive: Why Creativity is the Key to an AI-Future

contributors.name: Ned Johnson
contributors.title: President
contributors.details: Ned Johnson is the president and founder of PrepMatters. A professional tutor-geek since 1993, Mr. Johnson has devoted in excess of 35,000 hours in one-on-one test prep for nearly the entire alphabet of tests. His experience includes work with all ages and abilities in preparation for SSAT and ISEE to ACT and SAT to GMAT, GRE and LSAT.Considered by many to be the most sought-after instructor in the Washington, DC metropolitan area, Mr. Johnson has served area students as well as clients from across the country and around the globe.  In addition to his time with clients, Mr. Johnson oversees instructor hiring and training, curriculum development, business management, and coffee purchases.A 1993 graduate of Williams College, Mr. Johnson has a BA in Economics and Political Science. Originally from Connecticut (he can drive in snow), Mr. Johnson now resides with his wife and children in Washington, DC.People often believe standardized tests are IQ tests.  They aren’t.You have to know what’s on the tests.  You have to know how to do what’s on them.  And, you have to be able to do your best on any given day.  All are knowledge and skills that you can develop — that’s what I help you do.  Along the way, we might even help you learn more about the ways you study, think and perform that can could be meaningful to you long after you have forgotten what your test scores were.

contributors.name: Ifeoma Ajunwa
contributors.title: Associate Dean
contributors.details: Dr. Ifeoma Ajunwa is a tenured professor, Associate Dean at Emory Law, and Founding Director of its AI and Future of Work Program. A Yale Law and Columbia Ph.D. graduate, she’s a leading scholar on the ethical governance of workplace tech. She has advised Fortune 500 companies, testified before Congress, and written for top law journals, Forbes, and major media outlets. Her book The Quantified Worker is forthcoming from Cambridge University Press.

contributors.name: Mike Pell
contributors.title: Envisioneer. Author. Outlaw.
contributors.details:
Bold, insightful, and uncompromising, Mike Pell regularly disrupts the thinking, strategy, and business models of the world’s most successful companies and organizations. Widely recognized as a world-class Designer and industry thought leader in the fields of Innovation, Visualization , and Data + AI, Pell currently leads The Microsoft Garage in New York City. His evolution from intrepid entrepreneur, to VC-backed startup veteran, to corporate man for Adobe and Microsoft has given him a unique perspective on how to combine business, design, and technology to create breakthrough experiences.  

Learn more at https://Mike-Pell.com

contributors.company: The Center for Arts & Innovation, Inc.
contributors.name: Andrea Virgin
contributors.title: Chair & CEO
contributors.details:
Andrea Virgin is a visionary leader whose life and work exist at the crossroads of creativity and resilience. A former professional ballerina turned civil engineer, entrepreneur, and nonprofit founder, her journey embodies the power of reinvention—and how creativity, when embraced across every field of life, can be profoundly transformative.

After performing with Houston Ballet II and Ballet Florida, Andrea earned degrees from Florida Atlantic University and Cornell University, transitioning from the stage to the built environment. She went on to launch her own firm, Virgin Design, where she infused human-centered creativity into land development. Once an anomaly for bridging the arts and engineering, she became determined to make creativity the rule in a future that demands more imagination, not less.

That mission inspired her founding of The Center, where she serves as Chair & CEO. Under her leadership, The Center has raised nearly $25 million, engaged Pritzker Prize-winning Renzo Piano Building Workshop, and positioned itself to redefine creativity and its role in society for the 21st century.

A sought-after speaker on creativity, resilience, and technology, Andrea has been featured at CreativeMornings, BitBasel, Leading Between the Lines, Launching Simplified, and Quantum Beach 2025. Her work has been recognized by Palm Beach Illustrated’s Women On Top, The Palm Beach 100, and Boca Magazine’s Fantastic Four.

When she’s not leading transformative initiatives, Andrea finds creative renewal with her daughters and husband—or on the ballroom dance floor at Fred Astaire Dance Studio in Boca Raton.

description: AI may make life easier, but at what cost to our imagination? Like a bike we stop riding, our creativity weakens when we overrely on AI. Still, while adults may feel rusty, we can get back on. For children, the risk is even greater: if they never build that muscle in the first place—never learn to ride at all—there’s nothing to return to. This all comes just as jobs are being disrupted, problems grow more complex, and we need more imagination, not less. This panel explores how we can grow creatively with AI (versus be diminished by it) and what we must build now to make that future possible.
long_description: AI may make life easier, but at what cost to our imagination? Like a bike we stop riding, our creativity weakens when we overrely on AI. Still, while adults may feel rusty, we can get back on. For children, the risk is even greater: if they never build that muscle in the first place—never learn to ride at all—there’s nothing to return to. This all comes just as jobs are being disrupted, problems grow more complex, and we need more imagination, not less. This panel explores how we can grow creatively with AI (versus be diminished by it) and what we must build now to make that future possible.

name: Convene, Collaborate, & Cultivate Connection: Moms Meet Up

contributors.name: Loraine Martinez Bellamy
contributors.title: Lawyer and Life & Business Coach
contributors.details:
Loraine Martinez Bellamy, is a Puerto Rican lawyer turned life and business coach
dedicated to helping fellow women of color do less, make more, and be more present in
their beautiful lives. Through her private coaching practice and social media presence,
she helps lawyers and leaders own their expertise, outsource their weaknesses, and
develop empowered and effective teams. Many of Loraine’s clients also decide to
expand beyond their successful careers into more creative endeavors with her coaching
support. Loraine’s work is couched in a deep understanding of the tension between
having an analytical, often-anxious, type-A brain, while also craving freedom,
connection, and creativity.

contributors.name: Erica Rooney
contributors.title: CEO & Founder | Chief Human Resource Officer
contributors.details:
Erica Anderson Rooney is a C-suite executive, keynote speaker, bestselling author, and unapologetic ceiling-shatterer. With over 15 years of HR and leadership experience—including her role as Chief People Officer—Erica has built her career helping organizations transform cultures and helping women claim their rightful seat at the table.
She’s the founder of HER Collective, a thriving digital community designed to help women advance their careers, amplify their voices, and unlock their full potential—without sacrificing authenticity or well-being. Erica also hosts the top-rated Glass Ceilings & Sticky Floors podcast and is the author of the bestselling book Glass Ceilings & Sticky Floors: Shattering Limiting Beliefs and Toxic Behaviors to Uncover Infinite Possibilities.
Her work has been featured in Forbes, SUCCESS Magazine, and CBS News, and she’s taken the stage at SXSW, SHRM, and CHIEF. Recognized with multiple leadership awards, Erica is known for her dynamic storytelling, tactical takeaways, and ability to ignite change.
Whether in the boardroom, on stage, or behind the mic, Erica is on a mission to empower women everywhere to rise above the sticky floors, break through the glass ceiling, and lead with limitless possibility.

description: Calling all Moms: Join women from diverse backgrounds, all united by their shared experience of balancing professional ambitions and motherhood. Here, we aim to create a supportive and empowering environment where moms can network, share insights, and build lasting connections. Expect: Networking Opportunities to exchange ideas, experiences, and strategies that help you thrive, collaborative discussions about the unique strengths and skills moms bring to the table, and cultivate connections with women who can offer advice, encouragement, and friendship long after SXSW ends.

contributors.name: Maab Ibrahim
contributors.title: Head of Economic Opportunity
contributors.details: Maab is the Head of Economic Opportunity for the Americas at Google.org, a data-driven, human-focused philanthropy powered by Google. Through a blend of funding, products, and technical expertise from Google volunteers, she accelerates the work of nonprofits that create pathways for people to gain the technical and AI skills they need to thrive in the digital economy. Prior to Google, Maab worked on community partnerships for the federal government at the White House and Department of Health and Human Services. She later joined Values Partnerships, a social impact agency that connected foundations and companies with grassroots influencers. A native of Richmond, Virginia, Maab received a degree from Duke University and a dual MBA/MPP from the University of Michigan.

contributors.name: Winston Fan
contributors.title: High School Student And 4-H’er
contributors.details: Winston Fan is a senior at West High School in Iowa City who is passionate about using AI and psychology to improve mental health. Since his freshman year, he has been actively involved in scientific research, spending more than two years developing AI-based tools to better understand and support emotional well-being. He has been named Grand Champion at both regional and state science fair competitions in Iowa and has competed at the International Science and Engineering Fair twice, placing 4th in the Behavioral Sciences category during his second year. Beyond research, he enjoys mentoring younger students, exploring emerging technologies, and finding creative ways to make a positive impact in his community.

contributors.name: Dr. Mark Light
contributors.title: 4-H Specialist
contributors.details:
I am a faculty member at North Carolina State University and previously served at The Ohio State University, with a career specializing in STEM and technology education, particularly in creating equitable access for underserved and rural communities. As a 4-H STEM Specialist, I lead Artificial Intelligence literacy, coding, and digital equity initiatives, including a Google-funded national effort to develop inclusive AI curricula. 

I also direct mobile outreach programs that bring robotics, coding, and hands-on STEM experiences directly to youth. My mission is to ensure all learners—regardless of background—have the skills and confidence to thrive in a rapidly changing, technology-driven world. As the 4-H STEM Specialist at North Carolina A&T University, I am passionate about working with youth and helping them develop into adults who can create, innovate, and solve problems with technology.

contributors.name: Jill Bramble
contributors.title: President & CEO
contributors.details: Jill Bramble, 4-H alum and President & CEO of National 4-H Council, embodies the transformative power of youth development. Formerly Chief Growth Officer, she led efforts to expand access to 4-H through strategic partnerships and innovation. Today she leads the Beyond Ready initiative, which aims to equip 10 million young people with essential skills for the future. Under her direction, 4-H is expanding career readiness and mental health programs, activating its extensive alumni network, and partnering with educators nationwide to ensure 4-H continues to prepare youth to be beyond ready to thrive in our rapidly-changing world. Jill received a BSc in Kinesiology from the University of Colorado and a Master of Science in Nonprofit Administration from the University of Maryland.

Join this session to explore why equitable access to AI education and support for youth-led innovation are essential to building prosperity and resilience across communities and industries.

name: The Creative Power of Letting Go: Why Quitting Can Be Your Biggest Breakthrough

contributors.name: Kerry Flynn
contributors.title: Media Reporter
contributors.details: Kerry Flynn is a media reporter at Axios and co-runs Media Trends Executive, a new membership program with Sara Fischer that provides exclusive news, data and analysis for media professionals. She keeps a close eye on advertising, marketing, digital media and the creator economy. She frequently moderates at events and conferences, including Advertising Week, SXSW and Cannes, and speaks on TV news, radio and podcasts. Kerry joined Axios from CNN, where she covered the business of media for CNN.com and the Reliable Sources newsletter. She previously reported on tech and social media at Digiday and Mashable. Kerry lives in Greenpoint, Brooklyn with her husband and their dog, Falkor. Her handle across social media platforms is @kerrymflynn

contributors.name: Charlie Engelman
contributors.title: Creator
contributors.details: Charlie Engelman is an Emmy-winning television producer, content creator, and science communicator. His project, Odd Animal Specimens, featuring natural history specimens from museums around the United States, has generated over 4 billion views and over 10 million followers across platforms. He was recently named to TIME's list of the 100 most influential creators on the internet and also holds an academic position at the University of Michigan Museum of Zoology.

description: In a culture built on hustle, knowing when to walk away can be a Creator’s most powerful advantage. Emmy-winning Creator and TIME Next 100 honoree Charlie Engelman joins Axios Media reporter Kerry Flynn for a candid conversation exploring the surprising role that quitting plays in creative success.  After eight years chasing projects that never took off, Charlie found success only when he stepped back and started fresh. Together, they’ll explore how to recognize when a project is holding you back, why letting go is not failure but a strategic move, and how smart quitting can be an essential skill for anyone building a sustainable career in today’s Creator Economy.

contributors.name: Neerav Kingsland
contributors.title: Head Of Strategic Initiatives
contributors.details: Neerav Kingsland works at Anthropic, shaping how advanced AI systems are deployed responsibly in the real world. Before Anthropic, Neerav spent more than a decade leading large-scale civic and education systems change. He previously served as Managing Partner at The City Fund and as CEO of New Schools for New Orleans, where he helped guide the city’s post-Katrina transformation of its public education system.

contributors.name: Marlon Marshall
contributors.title: CEO
contributors.details: Marlon Marshall is Chief Executive Officer of City Fund, where he leads efforts to ensure all students have access to high-quality public schools. He brings deep experience from government, national campaigns, and organizational leadership to advance transformative change in public education. Prior to City Fund, Marlon was a founding partner at 270 Strategies and served in senior roles in the Obama White House Office of Public Engagement, the 2012 Obama reelection campaign, and the 2016 Hillary for America campaign. He currently serves on the board of the Equitable Facilities Fund.

contributors.name: Frances Messano
contributors.title: CEO
contributors.details: Frances Messano is CEO of NewSchools Venture Fund, a venture philanthropy that builds a better education system by connecting people, resources, and ideas. Throughout her 10 year tenure, Frances has served as President, created the Diverse Leaders investment strategy, and led the Innovative Schools team. Before joining NewSchools, Frances had senior roles at Teach for America and Monitor Institute.Frances, a first-generation college graduate, earned an MBA from Harvard Business School and A.B. from Harvard College. She is an alum of Prep for Prep, MLT and SEO, nonprofits that profoundly influenced her trajectory, and she serves on numerous non-profit boards centered on increasing access to opportunity. Frances lives in San Francisco with her husband and their three children, who attend NewSchools portfolio schools.

contributors.name: Adeel Khan
contributors.title: Founder & CEO
contributors.details: Adeel Khan is the Founder and CEO of MagicSchool AI, a platform used by educators to support planning, feedback, and instruction through responsible AI tools. Before founding MagicSchool, Adeel was a teacher, assistant principal, and founding principal of a high-performing public high school in Denver. His work focuses on helping educators integrate AI in ways that strengthen teaching practice and reduce workload.

description:
AI tools are improving quickly, and educators are already finding meaningful uses for them. What hasn’t been defined yet is the school model that makes AI work for students and teachers in a coherent, reliable way at scale.

This session examines what early adopters of AI in public education are learning in real classrooms and school systems, the concrete design choices and conditions behind early success, and the operational, instructional, and governance questions that must be resolved over the next five years for AI to strengthen public education rather than fragment it.

name: Workforce Innovation in Production & the Creative Economy

contributors.name: Kate Berezo
contributors.title: Director of  Workforce Programs & Partnerships
contributors.details: Kate Berezo is a workforce strategist working at the intersection of education, social capital, and the entertainment industry. As Director of Programs at Hollywood CPR, she oversees strategy and workforce partnerships that connect emerging talent to high-wage below-the-line union careers in film, television, and live events. Her work focuses on how informal hiring systems, access to networks, and capital shape who gets hired, and who doesn’t. Previously, Kate scaled national workforce initiatives at Thrive Scholars, expanding employer partnerships and job placement outcomes across technology, finance, and other sectors in multiple markets. Her work translates complex labor systems into practical strategies for educators, institutions, and employers navigating rapidly changing industries.

contributors.name: Ashlee Hypolite
contributors.title: Executive Director
contributors.details: Ashlee Hypolite is the Executive Director of Hollywood Cinema Production Resources, a nonprofit training individuals from various backgrounds in production crafts and technical skills for the entertainment industry. With over a decade of experience across nonprofit, entertainment, and philanthropy, she brings strategic leadership to inclusive workforce development. Previously, Ashlee led 30+ celebrity-guided funds at the Entertainment Industry Foundation, managed high-impact charitable initiatives including Social Change Fund United, and supported social impact projects at the CAA Foundation, including TIME’S UP. She began her career advising foundations and major donors at the Boston Foundation and is a graduate of Brandeis University.

description: How can we reimagine training and workforce development in film, media, and the creative industries as technology, production models, and industry needs rapidly evolve? This meetup convenes educators, workforce leaders, and entertainment professionals to explore innovative approaches for preparing set-ready talent and upskilling current professionals. Participants will share strategies, examine gaps, and discuss how policy levers like film tax credits, emerging technology, and cross-sector collaboration can create scalable, equitable pathways from education to sustainable careers.
