name: Vibrating Music Hammocks
long_description:
The Music Hammock transforms its fabric into a speaker, resonating your body with the frequencies of the music so you feel as if you’re lying inside a sound system. In our fast-paced society, we often disconnect from our bodies. This installation offers a full-body listening experience, shifting your attention from mental chatter into physical awareness. Experience sound not only through your ears, but through your entire body.

contributors.title: Professor Emeritus of Art (retired)
contributors.details: Brian Evans is a digital artist and composer. His artwork and music animations are exhibited and screened internationally. Evans has published and presented extensively on his research in the integrating of image and sound. He also explores metaphoric thinking across domains and the computational modeling of creativity. He has presented on his work at SIGGRAPH, The Society of Neuroscience Conference and ACM Creativity and Cognition. Evans is a Professor Emeritus from the University of Alabama where he directed the program in digital media in the Department of Art and Art History.

description: Engaging art is a creative act. There are art galleries and museums everywhere. Let's use them well. Art objects aren't puzzles to solve, but rather invitations to experience something new and make it personally meaningful. As Josiah McElheny explains, “The experience of art is a kind of fusion of your experience of yourself and of the object.” In doing this personal creativity is exercised and you get smarter. This session will get you started on doing it well, showing how to exercise effectively.

name: Redbreast Unhidden Box Office
long_description:
The Redbreast Unhidden Box Office lands in Austin this SXSW, from March 12–14 on Congress Avenue, across from the iconic Paramount Theatre, celebrating exceptional Irish whiskey and cinema. Collect your ticket from our Redbreast concierges for an exclusive Redbreast Single Pot Still Irish Whiskey tasting and enjoy the chance to win prizes.

Attendees must be over 21. On-site registration required.

related_sales_client.name: Redbreast
related_sales_client.company_headline: Redbreast Unhidden: Unearthing films worth talking about.
related_sales_client.company_bio:
Discovering Redbreast is a revelation. That thrill of unearthing a hidden gem isn’t limited to whiskey bars – it lives wherever curious minds search for their next great find. That spirit brings us to the SXSW Film & TV Festival 2026 and year two of Redbreast Unhidden, our platform championing bold, original storytelling in film.

We’ve partnered with Irish actor Andrew Scott to spotlight exceptional talent in the Narrative Short competition and share it with the world. The must-see films of the category will be highlighted as our Redbreast Unhidden Selects, with one filmmaker receiving the prestigious Redbreast Unhidden Award at the SXSW Film & TV Awards on March 18th.

Join us March 15th at the Redbreast Unhidden Showcase for screenings of our selected films. You’re also invited to discover the Redbreast Unhidden Bar, tucked away in a secret Austin location from March 13th–14th, and attend an exclusive on-stage conversation between Andrew Scott and Deadline at the Omni Hotel on March 13th. And if that wasn’t enough, visit our surprise pop-up on Congress Avenue from March 12th–14th and experience our acclaimed Single Pot Still Irish Whiskey firsthand. For full details, scroll down or visit our website.

name: Keynote: Jennifer B Wallace

contributors.name: Jennifer B. Wallace
contributors.title: Bestselling Author
contributors.details: Jennifer Breheny Wallace is an award-winning journalist and bestselling author.   Her first book, Never Enough: When Achievement Culture Becomes Toxic — And What We Can Do About It, was a New York Times Bestseller, an Amazon Best Book of the Year, and a Next Big Idea selection. Her forthcoming book Mattering: The Secret to a Life of Deep Connection and Purpose, was published in January 2026.Wallace is the founder of The Mattering Institute, whose mission is to create cultures of mattering in workplaces and communities, and co-founder of The Mattering Movement, a nonprofit organization dedicated to creating cultures of mattering in schools. Jennifer is a Special Advisor to University Health & Counseling (UHC) at the University of Michigan and a member of their Well-being Collective Advisory Council. She is also on the Advisory Board for Making Caring Common, a project of the Harvard Graduate School of Education. Wallace is a Journalism Fellow at The Center for Parent and Teen Communication at the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia. She also served as a guest lecturer for NYU’s Fall 2025 course, Education, Mattering, and the American Dream: Understanding Achievement Culture.Wallace is a maternal mental health advocate at Calm, the mental health app, a consultant at Netflix, and a BCG  BrightHouse Luminary. She has also partnered with The LEGO Group on its global "Play Unstoppable" campaign, aimed at addressing perfectionism and fostering confidence through play.  Wallace started her journalism career at CBS's “60 Minutes” and was part of the team that won the Robert F. Kennedy Awards for Excellence in Journalism. She is a contributor to The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Post and frequently appears on national television programs.  Wallace serves on the board of the Coalition for the Homeless in New York City, where she lives.

Drawing on global research and powerful stories, she reveals how mattering offers a potent antidote to loneliness and burnout, and delivers practical takeaways to help people unlock mattering at home, at work, and in the wider world.

name: In Search of Hope: Teaching Climate Emotions Through Story

contributors.name: Mary-Katherine Menikheim
contributors.title: 5th Grade Classroom Teacher
contributors.details: Mary-Katherine is a fifth grade classroom teacher. She has been on the faculty at Marin Country Day School since 1998.

contributors.name: Colleen Redmond
contributors.title: PhD Student, Graduate Instructor, Research Assistant in Literacy Education, & Co-Founder paleBLUEdot
contributors.details: Colleen is a PhD student in Literacy Education at the University of Minnesota, where she also works as a graduate instructor in the Department of Curriculum & Instruction and a research assistant to the Marguerite Henry Professor of Children’s and Young Adult Literature. With a background in teaching, educational programming, and youth climate engagement, Colleen is passionate about expanding climate education to better address students’ emotional well-being. Her current research focuses on identifying hope in children’s climate literature as a pathway for supporting youth experiencing ecological grief and creating emotionally responsive, story-based classroom practices. Colleen is also the co-founder and youth and community engagement director at the climate consulting firm paleBLUEdot.

description: Climate change impacts students not just physically, but emotionally as well. This session introduces the H.O.P.E. Framework (Healing Opportunities for Processing Eco-Grief), a practical, story-based approach for helping teachers and students recognize and respond to climate emotions. Rooted in hope theory and literature, the framework offers tools to spark meaningful conversations and build emotional resilience. Participants will explore current research, hear from educators using the approach, and leave with ready-to-use resources for emotionally responsive climate education.

contributors.name: Emily Fammartino Quast
contributors.title: Director, People & Culture Business Partnering
contributors.details: Based in Portland, OR, Emily is Director of Business Partnering for People & Culture at lululemon, where she has spent the past 16 years shaping how leaders and teams grow, collaborate, and innovate. She began her lululemon journey in retail, developing a deep understanding of frontline leadership and the power of culture in action. That foundation continues to inform her work today as she partners with executive leaders across the Americas and Global Guest Innovation teams.

contributors.name: James Miles
contributors.title: Assistant Professor
contributors.details: James Miles worked as an educator in the New York City public schools for almost 20 years prior to moving to Seattle in 2017. Miles has worked internationally as an artist and educator, and his work has been featured in magazines, books, podcasts, and newspapers. Miles is an assistant professor at Seattle University, Chief Strategy Officer at Path with Art, and on the advisory board of SXSW EDU. His work has been featured in media including Complex magazine, the New York Times, Billboard Magazine, CBS, NBC, the US Department of Education, and more. His acclaimed Tedx Talk focuses on his mission to narrow achievement gaps using the arts as a tool to navigate systems of educational inequality. He is the author of Gotta Stay Fresh and you can learn more about James at FreshProfessor.com.

contributors.name: Kristy Fammartino
contributors.title: Teacher, 5th Grade
contributors.details: An experienced professional with 20+ years of leadership expertise as a print designer and brand manager, lead buyer and design director. She has successfully led branding and design initiatives for academic institutions, luxury goods retailers, non-profit organizations and small businesses. Kristy was a Director of Retail Development and Director of Styling in the apparel industry and regularly attend trade shows and industry events in Paris, New York and Seattle. She returned to public school teaching in 2019. She is well tuned in the management of humans to maximize both productivity and individual successes, through her work in both the corporate world and classroom, and she is dedicated to bridging the gap between what corporations do and what schools CAN do.

contributors.details: Jennifer Ferrari is a distinguished leader in the educational sector, uniquely positioned at the intersection of education and business. As the CEO & President of ERDI, she has married her extensive background in public education with her sharp business acumen to drive transformative solutions that meet the evolving needs of PK-12 education.Before ascending to her current role, Jennifer served as the VP & Chief Schools Officer for a pioneering education management organization, where she spearheaded strategic planning and organizational growth. Her 25-year public education background, spanning roles from middle school teacher to superintendent, with expertise in curriculum and instruction, leadership development, change management, and strategic planning, provides her with a unique perspective on the intersection of education and business, enabling her to lead with insight and innovation.Jennifer earned her doctorate in Educational Leadership & Policy Studies from Loyola University in Chicago

He led key initiatives including a K-12 Literacy Framework, Virtual School, and AI implementation. Jeff has been nationally recognized as a Top 100 Education Leader and is a frequent speaker on digital transformation and equity.

name: From Insight to Impact: Superintendents Share What Works

contributors.name: Doug Roberts
contributors.title: CEO & Founder
contributors.details: A Princeton graduate, Doug is a former public high school social studies teacher and EdTech business development executive who earned his EdM in Teaching and Curriculum from Harvard Graduate School of Education. For nearly 20 years, he worked with district leaders and EdTech entrepreneurs, eventually founding the Institute for Education Innovation (IEI) in 2018 to bridge the gap between these groups. IEI supports 100+ members, hosts national conferences, and runs programs like IEI:Lead, equity workshops, and the Supes’ Choice Awards, judged exclusively by superintendents. Passionate about equity, inclusion, and high-quality education, Doug connects K-12 leaders to foster innovation and student success.

events.name: Innovation Without Borders: The World’s Top EdTech Startups

description: Want to understand how superintendents make purchasing decisions? Join leaders from the Institute for Education Innovation (IEI), a national superintendent think tank committed to fostering meaningful partnerships between districts and ed tech innovators. IEI superintendents will share candid insights and firsthand experiences to help founders and executives design solutions that truly support student success. The conversation will be guided by a superintendent emeritus and a 20-year industry veteran who has helped hundreds of ed tech companies grow and scale effectively.
long_description: Want to understand how superintendents make purchasing decisions? Join leaders from the Institute for Education Innovation (IEI), a national superintendent think tank committed to fostering meaningful partnerships between districts and ed tech innovators. IEI superintendents will share candid insights and firsthand experiences to help founders and executives design solutions that truly support student success. The conversation will be guided by a superintendent emeritus and a 20-year industry veteran who has helped hundreds of ed tech companies grow and scale effectively.
sort: FROM INSIGHT TO IMPACT: SUPERINTENDENTS SHARE WHAT WORKS

Alongside her independent work, Sara directs and produces commercials for clients including Lego, Jordan, and Lululemon.

events.name: The Oldest Person in the World

image.alt_text: The Oldest Person in the World

thumbnail.alt_text: The Oldest Person in the World

long_description:
A new generation of parents, teens, and reformers are fighting back against Big Tech’s agenda to define the future of human connection. From Kristin, a mother pursuing legislative reform after losing her son, to Trisha, a young programmer building technology to stop cyberbullying, the film reveals how deeply the attention economy is reshaping us.

Blending intimate human stories with insights from leading experts in tech reform and digital wellbeing, "Your Attention Please" asks some of the most urgent questions of our time: Can we reclaim our autonomy? Can technology be redesigned to serve humanity? And what does a healthier relationship with the digital world look like for us and our kids?

With a Master’s in Communication Studies and a background in rhetoric and liberal arts from Texas State University, Grace blends analytical thinking with creative flair. She's passionate about building relationships—whether it’s with clients, reporters, or teammates—and thrives on crafting narratives that make people care. Known for her positive energy, attention to detail, and collaborative style, Grace delivers PR campaigns that are as thoughtful as they are impactful. She’s the kind of communicator who doesn’t just talk—she listens, learns, and leads with intention.

contributors.details:
Victoria Dominguez-Edington is a PhD student in the Department of Sociology at the University of Texas at Austin. Informed by her background working with startups and investors, Victoria's dissertation examines the startup fundraising process. Victoria is also a research consultant for Stanford University under the direction of Dr. Alicia Sheares (Department of Management Science and Engineering) on a Russell Sage Foundation funded project about entrepreneurship in the United States. 

Before working in the Austin startup community, Victoria spent nearly a decade working in education as a Director at a local tutoring center. Victoria holds a BA from Southwestern University and an MA from the University of Texas at Austin.

name: Featured Session: How to Support Resilient Youth in an AI World

contributors.name: Miriam Schneider
contributors.title: Director of Learning Initiatives
contributors.details: Miriam Schneider is a trusted leader with two decades of experience in edtech, building products and programs at the intersection of cutting edge technology and educational impact. She currently serves as the Director of Learning Initiatives at Google DeepMind, where she leads efforts to explore how the future of AI can help advance and augment teaching, learning and human development. She’s deeply committed to cultivating collaboration across the broader education ecosystem to ensure that AI is grounded in learning science, built responsibly, researched rigorously, distributed equitably and fosters durable outcomes. Miriam’s fingerprints are etched throughout Google’s history in learning and education. During her tenure, she has built and led high-performing marketing and strategy teams across the company’s broad portfolio of education products, including Google Classroom and Chromebooks. She has been a foundational architect of Google’s holistic approach to education, dating back to the company’s early days roadtripping to college campuses in an iconic 1970s biodiesel school bus. More recently, she introduced LearnLM — the world’s most pedagogical AI — and has helped establish global advisory boards, student-focused programs, and communities of practice to enhance engagement with leading industry experts, practitioners and learners. Miriam is known for her unwavering passion for her work, innate desire to elevate and celebrate educators, and steadfast belief that everyone deserves access to high quality learning experiences. She believes the world runs on relationships and that curiosity is our currency of connection. She is an avid crafter (letterpress and calligraphy), active mother (to Poppy and Owen), podcast enthusiast (welcomes all recommendations!) who tries to forest bathe as much as possible. She graduated Summa Cum Laude and Phi Beta Kappa from UCLA and studied French at the Sorbonne.

contributors.name: Martin McKay
contributors.title: Executive Chair & Founder
contributors.details: Martin McKay, Executive Chair & Founder, EverwayMartin founded Everway (formerly Texthelp) in 1996 with a mission to create technology that empowers everyone to communicate more effectively. What started as a company focused on supporting individuals with speech and dexterity challenges has evolved into a leader in neuroinclusive technology, helping people of all abilities read, write, and express their ideas more fluently.Martin's vision is to unlock the potential of every brain by developing tools that address the unique needs of individuals. Under his leadership, Everway has impacted over 250 million people worldwide, with a goal of reaching one billion by 2030.Everway now employs 600 people across North America, Europe, and Australia and is backed by Five Arrows, the private equity arm of the Rothschild family. Martin’s dedication to improving literacy and communication has earned him recognition, including the Presidential Award from the International Dyslexia Association for his lifetime contribution to dyslexia and literacy.In 2022, Martin was named EY Entrepreneur of the Year (Ireland), celebrating his vision and leadership in making neuroinclusive technology accessible to all.

contributors.name: Maureen Polo
contributors.title: CEO
contributors.details: Maureen Polo is the CEO of Hello Sunshine, a multichannel media company that places women at the center of every story it creates, celebrates, and discovers. An award-winning leader with over 20 years of experience scaling high-growth media businesses, she was elevated to CEO in 2025 after joining Hello Sunshine in 2022 as Head of Direct-to-Consumer. In that role, she oversaw social, editorial, marketing, communications, and DTC brands, driving significant expansion of the company's direct-to-consumer offerings.Prior to Hello Sunshine, Maureen ran marketing strategy and solutions for Warner Media’s entertainment properties including HBO Max, TBS, truTV, Turner, Adults Swim, and Cartoon Network. In her previous role as General Manager at Fullscreen, Maureen ran the 400-person next generation entertainment company. Throughout her career Maureen has worked at a mix of traditional agencies and media companies where she excelled at leading start-up digital businesses specializing in the development and execution of cutting-edge cross-platform marketing and branded entertainment. She spent almost a decade at Conde Nast, led the sales and integrated marketing solutions team for Allrecipes.com, and worked with Rachael Ray & CBS to build and sell bespoke in-show, digital, and social integrations- essentially helping to build the industries original digital celebrity. Polo has been consistently recognized for their industry-leading work, including Shorty, Cannes Shortlist, OMMA, Streamy, RealScreen, Brandweek Constellation, and Digiday awards. Polo has also won Ad Age 20 under 30, She Runs It: Changing the Game Awards, and Cynopsis Top Women in Digital. Polo has also been profiled in Thrive Global’s Women Leadership series and featured in Forbes and Inc.

contributors.name: Rebecca Winthrop
contributors.title: Senior Fellow And Director
contributors.details: Rebecca Winthrop is a leading global authority on education, the director of the Center for Universal Education at Brookings and an adjunct professor at Georgetown University. She is dedicated to ensuring that every child has the opportunity to thrive in life, work, and as an engaged citizen. She leads cutting-edge research and initiatives aimed at transforming education systems around the world to better support children's learning and development.  Rebecca is a trusted advisor to both school communities and national and international organizations. Her expertise is sought by many including parent networks, schools, district education leaders, the White House, the United Nations, and Fortune 500 companies. Rebecca's work is centered on developing and advocating for evidence-based strategies that bring people together—families, educators, policymakers, and companies—to help children maximize their potential.  She holds a PhD from Columbia University’s Teachers College, an MA from its School of International and Public Affairs, and a BA from Swarthmore College.

description:
Generative AI is rapidly reshaping how young people learn, connect, and understand themselves. From AI tutors and creative tools to always-on digital companions, these technologies promise new opportunities, but also raise urgent questions about children’s cognitive, social, and emotional development. Rather than focusing on whether AI should be used in education, how do we ensure AI strengthens—rather than undermines—young people’s capacity to think, relate, and thrive?

Drawing from the recent Brookings report "A New Direction for Students in an AI World: Prosper, Prepare, Protect,” with data across 50 countries, this panel will include a rich mix of perspectives and explore what it truly means to support resilient youth in an AI-saturated world.
long_description:
Generative AI is rapidly reshaping how young people learn, connect, and understand themselves. From AI tutors and creative tools to always-on digital companions, these technologies promise new opportunities, but also raise urgent questions about children’s cognitive, social, and emotional development. Rather than focusing on whether AI should be used in education, how do we ensure AI strengthens—rather than undermines—young people’s capacity to think, relate, and thrive?

Drawing from the recent Brookings report "A New Direction for Students in an AI World: Prosper, Prepare, Protect,” with data across 50 countries, this panel will include a rich mix of perspectives and explore what it truly means to support resilient youth in an AI-saturated world.

Matt brings experience leading strategy teams and consulting with Boards, Management Teams and Marketing Leaders across corporate, brand, and sponsorship strategy. Prior to the greater, he was VP, Strategy at MKTG Canada (Dentsu) where he oversaw the delivery of strategic planning and creative services to leading brands across Canada investing in sponsorships across sport, entertainment, art, and cause. Matt has been recognized by the 5 to Watch Awards which honors Sports Business leaders under 40, teaches part-time in George Brown College's Sport marketing program and is a Board Member for PS43 Foundation (Pascal Siakam's charity).

name: Mentor Session: Patches Seely MBA, BSN, RN, CAVRN (Providence Health)

contributors.name: Patches Pace Seely, MBA, BSN, RN, CAVRN
contributors.title: Product Manager
contributors.details: Patches Seely MBA, BSN, RN, CAVRN has served the healthcare industry as a ClinicalExecutive for 20+ years in both the provider and healthcare services sectors. Patches hasspent over half of her career in both clinical and operational leadership roles ranging frominpatient care delivery, clinical informatics & analytics, patient logistics, ambulatory anddiagnostic scheduling, clinical surveillance, and virtual nursing services inside a large,multi-state, integrated delivery organization.In healthcare services, she served as the EVP of Clinical Solutions providing clinical strategydevelopment to a healthcare engagement organization who served health plans, providers, andemployers from all 50 states and the Philippines.Patches is currently consulting as a Clinical & Business Advisor to a health technologycompanies (mid-size & start up) as well as health systems focusing in on clinical and operationaloutcomes, workflow enhancements, workforce management & leadership techniques forchange management and go-to-market strategy.Additionally, Patches is a co-founder in a data security company with potential to makeorganizations and subsequently consumers, more protected from breaches in their data.When she started her own consultancy, she began working with organizations whose missionwas grounded in access, quality care and a commitment to building a culture of excellence. Thevastness of Patches’ experience affords her the ability to lead on multiple fronts, communicatewith all roles and role types and find and foster the best in individuals.Patches has spoken nationally on topics like AI, cybersecurity, virtual nursing, command centerapproaches to care, virtual/remote team dynamics, communications and the impact to clinicalsafety. Her influence has reached academia through her participation in a virtual nursingcertification and continued virtual nursing practice standards. Additionally, she’s participated inpodcasts covering topics like AI, drug diversion, safety & high reliability principles and recentlybrought her body of qualitative research on Being a Professional in Transition to a webinar.Patches has deep expertise in organizational adoption of new ways of working, technology,process automation and disruption of work through innovation. She has experienced thehealthcare system as a registered nurse, a leader, a patient, an advocate for aging familymembers and is continually inspired to keep “fixing” a system that is cumbersome for those welove.Patches received her Bachelors in Psychology from Louisiana State University, her Bachelors in Nursing from LSU Health Sciences Center and her MBA from University of Texas at Tyler.

contributors.name: Mikayla Hopkins
contributors.title: Head Of Marketing
contributors.details: Mikayla Hopkins is Head of Marketing at Tracksuit, the always-on brand tracking platform helping marketers measure and grow brand impact with clarity and confidence. With experience spanning consumer and SaaS brands, she combines strategic rigour with creative storytelling to build B2B marketing that’s distinctive, human and commercially effective.

contributors.name: Duncan Joseph
contributors.title: Creator / Comedian
contributors.details: Duncan Joseph, known online as duncanyounot, is a leading digital creator and has built a devoted global audience of over 9.5 million fans and established him as a standout voice in the creator world. Now expanding his career into fashion, hosting, acting, writing, and directing, his newest merch line, “You Can’t Arrest a Diva,” highlights his growing presence in style and his long-term vision of developing his own fashion brand. Duncan is also building out original concepts, including a new interview series that connects online creators with talent across entertainment and culture. With an evolving creative portfolio and a distinctive comedic point of view, Duncan is shaping his path as a multi-hyphenate talent in both digital and traditional media.

contributors.name: Katherine Miller
contributors.title: Director, Social Media
contributors.details: Katherine Miller is the driving force behind Hot Topic's vibrant online presence, leveraging over 15 years of expertise in social media strategy and execution. Her journey began in entertainment, navigating various roles within recording labels before finding her passion in ""new media.""Currently leading Hot Topic's social media department, Katherine has propelled the team from two to nine specialists, achieving a reach of over 15 million. Her keen eye for emerging trends and audience dynamics allows her to craft authentic connections, setting new benchmarks for brand engagement.With a dedication to innovation, Katherine is committed to shaping the future of brand and retail strategies. She eagerly shares her insights and experiences with fellow industry leaders, driven by a mission to revolutionize digital storytelling and foster customer loyalty.

contributors.name: Dan Salkey
contributors.title: Founder
contributors.details: Dan Salkey is Strategy Partner at Small World, the entertainment-first agency behind work for brands like Duolingo, Oatly, and Dr. Squatch. He helps brands act less like advertisers and more like entertainers, building creative teams of un-standard talent and turning marketing into culture. Dan also co-authored the Entertain or Die report, a global index ranking the most entertaining brands on Earth. His mission: help brands earn attention by being worth watching.

description: Malls may be losing commercial relevance, but some brands are reclaiming their cultural relevance. In a widely successful experimental pilot, Hot Topic has launched two social-first sitcoms shot entirely in malls, casting creators from punk, goth, and cosplay scenes to reclaim its ALT roots. As Gen Z flocks back to IRL hangouts and “third places,” the brand is transforming shopping centres into entertainment stages. It’s part of a wider shift toward entertainment-first marketing, echoing moves by brands like Dick’s Sporting Goods, which have built in-house studios to power the growth of their own and partner brands. Hear from Hot Topic and their agency partners Small W•rld about how to pull this strategy off successfully.

Hear from Hot Topic and their agency partners Small W•rld about how to pull this strategy off successfully.

contributors.name: Tricia Patrick
contributors.title: Irani Foundation Director of Education
contributors.details: Tricia Patrick is an arts administrator who believes in the arts as a catalyst for conversation and change. Her pursuit of a performance career took her across the country and beyond, eventually landing in Berlin, Germany. There she developed her skills as an educator and workshop facilitator. Upon her return to the United States, she took on the leadership of a small children's theater company in New York City. She has worked as the Director of Community Engagement for Working Theater and the Director of Education and Public Engagement at MCC Theater in New York City. Tricia was a member of the inaugural 2020 BIPOC Leadership Circle and in the spring of 2022, she completed the Theater Producers of Color, Producing 101 certificate program.

contributors.name: Mia Nagawiecki
contributors.title: Senior Vice President, Education
contributors.details: Mia Nagawiecki is leading Colonial Williamsburg’s ambitious new digital and educational outreach initiatives, seeking to bring early American history and civic engagement efforts to tens of millions of people. Under her direction, Colonial Williamsburg is building a national coalition of history museums and civic education organizations to build collaborative digital resources to serve K-12 teachers and students, all to ensure that the nation’s 250th anniversary is a moment of collective learning for the nation. Prior to joining Colonial Williamsburg, Nagawiecki served as the Center for Civic Education’s Vice President and Chief Operating Officer, where she worked to advance the Center’s mission of providing civic and constitutional education to students, teachers, and citizens.

contributors.name: Brenda Barr
contributors.title: Director of Education & Research
contributors.details: Dr. Brenda Barr is the Director of Education and Research at Makematic, where she leads the design of ClassSpark courses and oversees research, scripting, and factual accuracy across Makematic productions. Prior to this, she served as Senior Director for Educator Networks and Programs at National Geographic. Her career includes roles as a social studies teacher, state content specialist in Mississippi, district curriculum leader and principal in Colorado, and Assistant Director of Teaching and Learning at the Colorado Department of Education. With over 30 years of experience in curriculum, instruction, assessment, and educational media. Dr. Barr has presented at multiple conferences, including at NCSS, throughout the country.

contributors.name: Alissa Oginsky
contributors.title: Director of K-12 Education
contributors.details: Alissa Oginsky is the Director of K-12 Education at George Washington’s Mount Vernon. She is responsible for managing a team of amazing museum educators in supporting teachers and students nationwide through the facilitation of professional development programming, signature student leadership programs, and classroom resources. Prior to joining Mount Vernon in 2018, Alissa spent eleven years as a classroom teacher in Grades 3-6 and educational leader for her collaborative team, social studies department, district curriculum team, and in various roles in museums and cultural organizations. She holds an M.A. in Art Museum and Gallery Education from Newcastle University and a B.S. in Elementary Education from York College of Pennsylvania.

description: With the 250th anniversary of the United States nearing, the need for accurate, engaging, and factual instruction has never been more urgent. Educators need professional development that is both flexible and trustworthy. Museums and nonprofits - longstanding partners in education - are responding to this moment by reimagining professional learning through video-based formats that preserve the power of place and story. This panel explores how these organizations are using video to support educators in navigating today’s polarized educational landscape with clarity, confidence and integrity.

name: Future-Ready Frameworks for Higher Ed's Title IX Challenges

contributors.name: Maureen Holland
contributors.title: Attorney
contributors.details: As a member of the Institutional Response Group at Cozen O'Connor, Maureen's practice is focused on helping educational institutions improve policies, procedures, and systems for preventing and addressing discrimination, harassment, and interpersonal harm, including sexual assault, dating violence, domestic violence, stalking, sex- and gender-based harassment, identity-based discrimination and harassment, hazing, retaliation and other forms of conduct prohibited by Title VI, Title VII, Title IX, the Clery Act (as amended by the Violence Against Women Reauthorization Act), and related federal and state laws.Maureen helps schools design and implement effective institutional responses that integrate the complex federal and state regulatory framework with the unique dynamics of interpersonal harm. She provides hands-on assistance in building centralized offices of institutional equity, writing policies and procedures, conducting investigations, serving as an external decision-maker and appellate authority, and developing and delivering training programs for Title IX Coordinators, institutional equity personnel, decision-makers, investigators, and other implementers and leaders.Institutions regularly call upon Maureen to conduct external policy audits regarding Title IX, Title VI, and other civil rights laws; reviews of institutional responses to current or historical reports of sexual and gender-based harassment and violence; and child protection audits. She also assists schools in meeting federal compliance obligations and responding to investigations by the Office for Civil Rights and the Clery Compliance Division of the U.S. Department of Education.As a seasoned investigator, Maureen manages and conducts Title IX and civil rights investigations. She also serves as an external hearing officer, panel chair, and legal consultant to decision-makers in Title IX, discrimination, harassment, and related conduct cases.Maureen served as Interim Director of Civil Rights and Title IX at Amherst College (2024); Interim Director of Investigations at a large state university, restructuring their intake and investigative processes (2018-2019); and Interim Title IX Coordinator at Baylor University, helping to build Baylor’s Office of Institutional Equity (2017-2018). She currently leads a team of IRG attorneys who serve as equity consultants for Michigan State University, reviewing policies, procedures, and case files and reporting on legal compliance and effective practices.Maureen co-chairs the firm’s Education Industry team, helping identify, develop, and connect education leaders with legal advisors and experienced professionals within and outside of Cozen O’Connor. Maureen is also actively involved in the firm’s diversity initiatives and has previously served on the firm’s Member Committee and Hiring Committee. Maureen currently serves on the boards of Face to Face Germantown and Central Division Victim Services (CDVS) and is the co-chair of the Philadelphia Bar Association's LGBTQ+ Rights Committee. In 2020, Maureen was recognized as one of the best LGBTQ+ Lawyers under 40 by the LGBT Bar. In 2024, the Legal Intelligencer recognized Maureen as an “Unsung Hero” for her behind the scenes leadership in important matters. Maureen and her wife live in Philadelphia.

contributors.name: Lorie Dakessian
contributors.title: Attorney
contributors.details:
Lorie Dakessian represents clients in campus discipline cases, Title IX litigation, white-collar and internal investigations, and legal and medical malpractice matters.

As Co-Chair of the Title IX & Campus Discipline practice (www.titleix.law), Lorie represents college students and faculty members nationwide who are under investigation for, or who have been disciplined by their colleges or universities for, alleged violations of sexual harassment and misconduct and academic misconduct. She also represents faculty members who are under investigation by their universities and federal agencies for allegations of sexual harassment or research misconduct. She brings litigation against colleges and universities when a resolution cannot be reached at the disciplinary level.

contributors.name: Lin-Chi Wang
contributors.title: Attorney
contributors.details: Lin-Chi is a sexual misconduct investigator, focusing on Title IX, Title VII, Title VI, and anti-discrimination consulting, investigations, adjudications, and advising. She brings extensive experience serving in interim Title IX and Equal Opportunity positions for higher education institutions, writing policy, conducting high-profile investigations, and serving as a decision-maker in sexual misconduct adjudications. Her approach is not only fair and impartial, but also centers humane, culturally appropriate, and trauma-informed practices.

description: Our panel of experienced lawyers brings different perspectives to the evolving Title IX legal landscape. We are student advocates, policy designers, and on-the-ground implementers. We will share strategies for transforming Title IX challenges into opportunities and explore how forward-thinking institutions can move from reactive approaches toward sustainable, sound policies and fair processes that serve all students. Through case studies and practical frameworks, participants will learn strategies for balancing legal requirements with institutional values in the classroom and beyond.

contributors.name: Russell Lowery-Hart
contributors.title: Chancellor
contributors.details: Dr. Russell Lowery-Hart is the Chancellor of Austin Community College District, where he leads with a philosophy rooted in love and equity. He previously served as president of Amarillo College, which earned national recognition—including the 2023 Aspen Prize for Community College Excellence—under his leadership. A passionate advocate for student success and systemic transformation, Russell holds a PhD in interpersonal communication with a focus on gender and diversity.

contributors.name: Luke Rhine
contributors.title: Vice President
contributors.details: Luke Rhine is Vice President for Postsecondary Success at Rodel, focused on bridging education, workforce, and economic systems. He previously served in the Biden-Harris administration as Acting Assistant Secretary for Career, Technical, and Adult Education at the U.S. Department of Education. He also held senior roles in the Delaware Department of Education, helping launch the nationally recognized Delaware Pathways initiative. A former teacher and Fulbright scholar, he brings deep expertise in systems change.

contributors.name: Joel Vargas
contributors.title: Vice President, Education
contributors.details: Joel Vargas is vice president of the Education practice at JFF, where he leads initiatives to improve learning systems and outcomes nationwide. An expert in aligning high school, college, and career pathways, he has shaped state policy agendas, created model legislation, and provided technical assistance to education leaders. He previously launched JFF’s West Coast office and holds an EdD from Harvard and a BA in journalism from Boston University.

contributors.name: Jarrad Toussant
contributors.title: Senior Vice President, Education & Workforce
contributors.details: Jarrad Toussant is Senior Vice President of Education and Workforce at the Dallas Regional Chamber, where he leads efforts to build regional talent pipelines and expand economic mobility. A Texas native and public school graduate, Jarrad has held leadership roles with the Texas Education Agency, Teach For America, Citizen Schools, and the City of Newark. He holds master’s degrees in public and business administration from Rutgers and is a champion of education innovation and equity.

description: What if high school, college, and career weren’t separate systems—but one seamless experience designed to help today’s learners succeed in a fast-changing world of work? This panel explores “The Big Blur,” a bold vision to redesign how we educate 16–20-year-olds by erasing the boundaries between K–12, higher education, and work. Panelists will share how they’re building learning models that integrate academics, career-connected learning, and real credentials—starting in high school. Hear how these efforts are creating real opportunity for students and what it will take to scale nationwide.

contributors.title: Professor at the University of Sussex Business School & Co-Director of the ESRC Digital Futures at Work Research Centre (Digit)
contributors.details: Prof. Jacqueline O’Reilly, Director of Digit, the ESRC Digital Futures at Work Research Centre, unpacks how AI is shifting work, identity and collaboration, grounding future vision in new perspectives and real-world research. Jacqui leads international projects on the digital transformation of work and labour markets. With a doctorate from Oxford and a career spanning Europe and the US, she blends academic insight, policy expertise, and cultural analysis. A Fellow of the Academy of Social Sciences and former President of the Society for the Advancement of Socio-Economics, Jacqui brings rigorous evidence and a human lens to AI’s impact on society, making her a vital voice in shaping equitable, inclusive futures for work and learning.

description:
The metaphors we use shape the futures we create. While the whole world becomes human-AI hybrid, we still talk about AI like a god, ghost or omnipotent spreadsheet.
Corporate ‘cyborg-centaur’ sci-fi clichés trap organisations in macho, mechanistic tropes. We urgently need new myths to think with. Bring your sledgehammer as we deconstruct the lazy visual language of AI. Whether you’re designing tech, making art or building teams, the models unveiled in this session will give you the tools you need to take control and make AI an effective, equitable partner in the redesign of the new workplace.
long_description:
The metaphors we use shape the futures we create. While the whole world becomes human-AI hybrid, we still talk about AI like a god, ghost or omnipotent spreadsheet.
Corporate ‘cyborg-centaur’ sci-fi clichés trap organisations in macho, mechanistic tropes. We urgently need new myths to think with. Bring your sledgehammer as we deconstruct the lazy visual language of AI. Whether you’re designing tech, making art or building teams, the models unveiled in this session will give you the tools you need to take control and make AI an effective, equitable partner in the redesign of the new workplace.

name: Unleashing Students' Tech Genius to Improve Mental Health

contributors.name: Lisa Marsch
contributors.title: Director, Center for Technology and Behavioral Health
contributors.details: Lisa Marsch, PhD, directs Dartmouth’s Center for Technology and Behavioral Health and is a professor of psychiatry and biomedical data science. A global leader in digital therapeutics, she pioneered the first FDA-authorized digital treatment for opioid addiction, transforming mental healthcare. Her work focuses on developing additional therapeutics for HIV prevention, mental health, binge eating disorder, and more, blending cutting-edge technology with rigorous science. She is currently overseeing a student-led project that is developing a new AI tool that provides personalized real-time insights and recommendations to promote mental health and flourishing in student life. Lisa has previously given keynote speeches at the White House, World Bank, U.N., and Congress to share her work.

contributors.name: Keene Dampal
contributors.title: Student
contributors.details: Keene Dampal is a Dartmouth student from Davao City, Philippines. As someone who studies Neuroscience on the Pre-Med track, he is deeply passionate about youth mental health. He is actively involved with the Student Wellness Center as a Peer Wellness Coach, where he underwent specialized training to provide effective mental health support to students through wellness check-ins. He is also a pioneering project assistant at Evergreen, a student-led AI mental health project, where he contributed to content creation and ensured the inclusion of motivational interviewing in the platform's development. Outside the mental health sphere, he enjoys working with children at the Dartmouth College Child Care Center.

contributors.name: Asli Tavasli
contributors.title: Student
contributors.details: Asli a computer science and biology major with a minor in human-centered design, with a passion about using technology to make healthcare more accessible, preventative, and equitable. Originally from Istanbul, Türkiye, she hopes to bring a global perspective to the intersection of wellness and innovation. She’s worked on projects that improve healthcare delivery from both provider and patient perspectives by combining computer vision with traditional pathology tools to bridge digital and global diagnostic workflows, and translating text into musical patterns to support speech therapy. As an active contributor to a student-led AI mental health project, she focuses on developing applications that expand access to mental health solutions.

description: Panelists will discuss emerging tech-driven mental health solutions and the importance of involving end users – in this case, college students – in their development. Centered on the student-led creation of a first-of-its-kind AI tool to support mental health, this discussion with the project’s researchers and students, moderated by Pulitzer-prize winning wellness journalist Tara Parker-Pope, will emphasize the need to let research guide how we integrate AI into healthcare to harness its benefits without creating new harms, all while empowering students to become ethical stewards of AI.

contributors.company: University of North Carolina at Charlotte
contributors.name: Jamie Kudlats
contributors.title: Assistant Professor of Educational Leadership
contributors.details: Jamie Kudlats, Ph.D., is an assistant professor of educational leadership at the University of North Carolina at Charlotte, where he prepares aspiring school and district leaders through research-informed and practice-oriented instruction. A former middle school math teacher and principal, his scholarship explores the more humanistic aspects of school leadership, particularly the principal-student relationship, leadership identity, and stress, coping, and well-being. His work also focuses on legal issues in schools and increasing educators’ legal literacy to strengthen leadership practice. He is the co-creator/host of the education law podcast Chalk & Gavel.

contributors.name: Christopher Thomas
contributors.title: Assistant Professor of Educational Leadership and Policy
contributors.details: Dr. Christopher Thomas is an Assistant Professor of Educational Leadership and Policy at the University of Florida and co-host of the Chalk & Gavel podcast. A former high school English teacher and practicing school law attorney, he holds a Ph.D. in Educational Policy and a J.D. from The Ohio State University. His research focuses on the intersection of education law, policy, and democratic governance. He is the author of Reclaiming Democratic Education (Teachers College Press).

Jamie Kudlats and Chris Thomas will explore the current legal landscape reshaping K–12 schools—from book bans and parental opt-out policies to religious liberty disputes and protecting our most vulnerable students. Jamie, a former middle school math teacher and principal, and Chris, a former English teacher and school attorney, will break down major legal shifts, key issues, and share insights to empower educators and advocates to navigate an evolving legal and political landscape.

contributors.name: Esther Benjamin
contributors.title: CEO
contributors.details: Esther T. Benjamin has been a global executive in the public, private, and civil society sectors for more than 25 years. Before joining WES as CEO and executive director, Esther worked with Laureate Education, Inc., a leading global higher education organization. Esther served as the Associate Director for Global Operations of the U.S. Peace Corps, and held senior management roles with the International Youth Foundation and the International Partnership for Microbicides.

contributors.name: Karin Fischer
contributors.title: Senior Writer
contributors.details: Karin Fischer is a senior writer at The Chronicle of Higher Education, covering international education and the politics of college access. She authors Latitudes, a popular global education newsletter, and her work has appeared in NPR, The New York Times, and EdSource. Karin is a research associate at UC Berkeley’s Center for Studies in Higher Education and a fellow at SUNY Albany. She’s received fellowships from the East-West Center and the International Reporting Project, with honors from the Education Writers Association, National Press Foundation, and Poynter Institute.

contributors.name: Fanta Aw
contributors.title: CEO
contributors.details: Dr. Fanta Aw is the executive director and CEO of NAFSA: Association of International Educators, the world’s largest international education association. A former NAFSA president (2013–2016), she is a thought leader on internationalization, DEI, global trends, and student mobility. Dr. Aw spent over 30 years at American University, where she held senior leadership roles and earned her PhD in sociology. A sought-after speaker and global voice, she has been featured in CNN, The New York Times, The Economist, and more.

contributors.name: Omar Chihane
contributors.title: Global General Manager
contributors.details: As GM of TOEFL, Omar leads the strategic direction and growth of the TOEFL iBT, drawing on his global experience as a tech entrepreneur and executive. Before joining ETS in 2024, he founded englease, an English teaching startup serving the Middle East and Africa. He previously held leadership roles at Siemens, Nokia, and Microsoft. Omar holds an MBA from London Business School and is a venture partner with Antler, mentoring emerging tech startups.

contributors.details: Tomáš Mejzlík is a public innovation leader and advocate for STEM education and creative technology. As director of FabLab Brno, the first open digital fabrication lab in the Czech Republic, and current head of VIDA! Science Center, he designs national-scale initiatives that inspire youth to engage with science, engineering, and innovation. He is the creator of the FabLab University Truck, a mobile makerspace that has introduced digital fabrication to over 35,000 students across hundreds of schools. Tomáš also spearheaded the Czech Republic’s successful bid to host FAB25, the world’s largest digital fabrication summit.

description: In an era of global challenges—from clean water to AI ethics—we need an avalanche of young innovators, yet STEM interest drops during the middle-to-high school transition. A 7,700-student study reveals 6 levers that raise engagement: meaningful experiences, parent influence, unlocking girls’ participation, courage/agency, clear career images, and reframing difficulty. Take away a shared language, tested patterns, and next steps for applying them through Activation → Identity → Career.

contributors.name: Paulo Aguiar
contributors.title: CREATOR
contributors.details:
Paulo Aguiar is an AI-first creator and creative partner for global brands. In the last year, he published 150+ original pieces on generative AI and creative experimentation, generating 100+ million organic views and building a community of 500K+ followers across platforms. He travels globally producing content, consulting, and speaking at leading industry festivals and conferences, including Cannes Lions, SXSW, Innovation Summit and CES. He also runs an education platform focused on practical, creator-led generative AI.
He has created and starred in campaigns for brands including NVIDIA, L’Oréal, Google, Meta, Samsung, Canva, and Chevrolet. Prior to going full-time as a creator, Paulo was a globally awarded Creative Director with 15+ years spanning creative leadership, marketing leadership, and entrepreneurship.

contributors.name: Vanessa Mathias
contributors.title: Co founder
contributors.details: Vanessa Mathias is a speculative futurist, strategist, and co-founder of White Rabbit, a futures research and experience design studio based in Brazil. She’s the author of Radical Reimagination and a frequent speaker at SXSW, TEDx, and international festivals. Her work explores how imagination, discernment, and decision-making are being reshaped by technology — and how to protect cognitive sovereignty in a world driven by automation. She’s known for creating immersive, participatory sessions that challenge and activate.

contributors.name: Kevin Ashton
contributors.title: Author
contributors.details: Kevin Ashton is a visionary technologist. He coined the term the Internet of Things, and cofounded the Auto-ID Center at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The Story of Stories: The Million-Year History of a Uniquely Human Art is his second book; his first book, How to Fly a Horse: The Secret History of Creation, Invention, and Discovery, was named 2015's Porchlight Business Book of the Year. Kevin's writing about innovation and technology has appeared in The New York Times, The Atlantic Monthly, Politico, and Wired, and he gives talks about storytelling, the future, and innovation to audiences all over the world. He lives in Austin, Texas.

His latest book THE STORY OF STORIES explores the intrinsic human nature of storytelling; delves into how stories are deeply embedded in our lives; and traces the evolution of storytelling from night fires to digital screens, social media, AI, and beyond. Kevin will read from the book, discuss its big ideas, take questions, and, after the talk, sign books at the SXSW bookstore.

name: LGBTQ+ & Friends Meet Up

contributors.name: Luis Gramajo
contributors.title: Founder
contributors.details:
I grew up knowing I had a gift: I could make anyone feel comfortable. I could read a room, ask the right question, see the joy in someone even when they're hiding it. For a long time, I didn't know what to do with that.

Then I picked up a camera.

Now I run Sunday Afternoon Project and Storytellers Photo Lab. With my photography I don't chase technical perfection. I chase real moments. Connection. Vulnerability mixed with confidence. I create spaces where people's walls come down, and that's when the actual magic happens. That's when you see yourself the way I see you, powerful, joyful, genuinely yourself.

My mission is simple: help people realize they're way more interesting, way more beautiful, way more capable than they give themselves credit for. And then prove it in photos and everything I do.

Because here's what I believe: you deserve to see yourself joyfully. And I'm here to help you get there.

contributors.name: Hans Schrei
contributors.title: Founder
contributors.details: Born and raised in Guatemala, Austin is home now. Ever wondered why some stories stick while others fade? As a former marketer turned cookie entrepreneur and nonprofit founder, I've found the answer: authenticity. At The Sunday Afternoon Project, we’re redefining storytelling. Our Fearless Storytelling™ workshops blend data with drama, creating authentic connections in a world of artificial engagement. My passion? Making complex ideas simple and engaging. Whether it’s the story behind a cookie or a life journey, I transform the intimidating into something accessible and impactful. Curious how your story could be a game-changer? Let’s chat—because in life’s big story, we’re all co-authors.

description:
Robots are no longer confined to factories. Today, they work in offices, live in homes, and support people in hospitals. But even the most advanced technical performance doesn’t ensure success. What often makes the difference? Likeability.

In this talk, we explore how product strategy, design and character development help robots go from impressive machines to trusted companions. Through real-world case studies, we’ll show how emotional connection can be just as important as capability.

sort: CHARMAGEDDON: ROBOTS THAT STEAL HEARTS AND JOBS

name: Exploring the Future of Space and Japan's Deep-Tech

contributors.name: Tomoki Osato
contributors.title: CEO
contributors.details: During his university years, he belonged to a “Birdman” club-Japan’s human-powered glider competition-and served as a pilot. He earned his bachelor’s degree in Physics and Materials Engineering from Nagoya University and conducted research as a Special Research Fellow at JAXA, focusing on carbon-nanotube-based composite materials. He later completed a master’s degree in Scientific and System Engineering at Nagoya University. After working in production engineering at IHI, a major Japanese heavy-industry manufacturer, he joined Sora Material and now serves as its CEO.

contributors.company: Deloitte Tohmatsu Venture Support Co., Ltd.
contributors.name: Nanako Hirano
contributors.title: Senior Consultant
contributors.details: As a Senior Consultant at Deloitte , She leverages her expertise in start-up consulting, emerging markets, and sustainable development to drive the creation and implementation of innovative business schemes. Her work focuses on fostering impactful solutions for startups addressing pressing social and environmental challenges in Japan and emerging markets. She previously served as an Associate Manager at Accenture and worked in the Democratic Republic of the Congo as an International Development Consultant for local enterprises. In her current role, she supports startups in their global expansion, including assisting space-related startups through Aichi Prefecture’s U.S. market programs as part of a local government initiative.

contributors.name: Jarek Khoilian
contributors.title: Investor
contributors.details: Jarek Khoilian leads the Aerospace, Space and Defense investment vertical at Woven Capital, Toyota's global growth stage venture fund. He has led strategic investments in Stoke Space, which is developing fully reusable rockets for next generation space access, in a US based satellite communications provider, and in Machina Labs, an advanced manufacturing company serving the aerospace and defense sectors. In 2025, he was named one of the Top 50 Rising Stars by Global Corporate Venturing.

description: Japan is rapidly emerging as a bold new force in space mobility. This session brings together Woven Capital, Innovative Space Carrier, Sora Material, and Deloitte to reveal how Japan’s deep-tech breakthroughs—reusable launch systems, orbital transportation architectures, and ultra-light materials that almost float in air—are reshaping the future of Earth-to-Orbit-to-Moon mobility. From Toyota’s global investment strategy to Japan’s first private U.S. VTVL launch, the speakers will share frontier insights and new opportunities for global collaboration with Japan’s rising space industry.

name: The Lie That You’re Not Creative

contributors.name: Jodie King
contributors.title: Founder & CEO
contributors.details: Jodie King is an Austin-based artist, educator, and mentor whose work focuses on creativity as an essential human skill rather than an artistic talent. Through years of teaching, community work, and one-on-one mentorship, she has helped people reconnect with creativity to navigate change, regain clarity, and build resilience during periods of transition. Jodie teaches globally through courses, workshops, and live programs, and hosts a widely followed podcast exploring creativity, identity, and meaningful work. She serves on the board of Art for the Streets (Austin, TX), bringing creative access into underserved communities, and was named one of the Top 50 Women Leaders of Austin in 2025. Her work has been featured by Forbes and NBC.

description: Creativity is no longer a “nice to have.” As technology takes over efficiency and execution, creativity has become the essential human skill – fueling clarity, adaptability, and connection in times of rapid change. This session reframes creativity not as talent, but as a core capability anyone can access. Through practical tools and real-world examples, participants will learn how creativity helps us navigate uncertainty, think more flexibly, and stay grounded, resilient, and human in an increasingly automated world.

long_description: American Doctor is a vérité non-fiction film following three prominent physicians–Palestinian, Jewish and Zoroastrian—friends who couldn’t be more different but are bound by the shared oath to heal. Dr. Thaer Ahmad is measured, Dr. Mark Perlmutter is blunt, and Dr. Feroze Sidhwa is steeped in scholarship. Filmed in unfolding, on-the-ground scenes, the story follows them from a Gazan hospital under siege, to the halls of Congress. Together they fight to keep a promise to their Palestinian colleagues and patients, which is to continue the struggle where it matters most: the United States.

name: Anima

contributors.name: Brian Tetsuro Ivie
contributors.details: Brian Tetsuro Ivie is a Japanese-American filmmaker, film producer, and the co-founder of Kebrado, a celluloid-only media company based in New York City. His most recent producing work includes the Oscilloscope-released, "Wildcat," starring Maya Hawke, Laura Linney, and Cooper Hoffman, which debuted at both the Telluride and Toronto Film Festivals before premiering on the Criterion Channel, “Even in the Wind,” starring Sonoya Mizuno, which premiered at Internationale Kurzfilmtage Winterthur, and the upcoming 16mm workplace comedy, "Concessions," starring Michael Madsen, Steven Ogg, and Josh Hamilton. Brian is currently writing an original science-fiction series with Cary Joji Fukunaga for David Oyelowo's Yoruba Saxon Productions based on his family's own experience with Japanese incarceration. As a director, he is in post on "Serenity," an intimate 16mm documentary about a multi-generational family in the Pacific Northwest. "Anima," starring Sydney Chandler and Takehiro Hira, is Brian's narrative feature film debut.

events.name: Black Zombie

long_description: Sean and his fiancée, Grace, enter a remote forest to find Sean’s missing father, Paul, who vanished after the death of his youngest daughter, Lilly. Returning to the site of Lilly’s death forces Sean to confront his inner demons, which begin to materialize externally. Their search takes a terrifying turn, revealing Paul’s secret. He’s been conducting cloning experiments, aimed at resurrecting Lilly. The forest is now inhabited by cannibalistic mutant girls, each a clone of Lilly, battling to prove their identity as the 'real' Lilly. As Sean and Grace uncover the grim truth, they face terrifying creatures and grapple with unsettling questions about life and death.

name: Agridulce (Bittersweet)

contributors.name: Frank Pavich
contributors.details: Frank directed "N.Y.H.C." (1999), on New York's hardcore music scene. He co-produced "Die, Mommie, Die!," winner of Sundance’s 2003 Special Jury Prize. His "Jodorowsky’s Dune" (2013) premiered at Cannes Quinzaine and was nominated for Golden Camera. The film received numerous prizes and acclaim.

contributors.name: Benjamin de Menil
contributors.details: Agridulce is de Menil's first feature film. He has for more than 25 years produced music recordings, videos, live tours, and educational materials related to Dominican music and dance. In 2013, he founded La Academia de Bachata, the world's first music school dedicated to bachata.

long_description:
In the Dominican town of Cabarete, bachata is a way of life far from the dance halls that it occupies overseas. A snapshot of four children, each confronting an existential challenge, Agridulce shows how music guides their journey of self discovery. With five years of filming, director Frank Pavich (Jodorowsky’s Dune) captures pivotal moments of the children’s coming of age.

Generations collide, and the children struggle for balance in a world troubled by conflict. Along the way, they’re mentored by teachers of a school devoted to bachata, the once denigrated music that has become the Dominican Republic’s primary cultural export.

name: Mile End Kicks

contributors.name: Chandler Levack
contributors.details:
Chandler Levack grew up in Burlington, Ontario and lives in Toronto, where she studied cinema at the University of Toronto and screenwriting at the Canadian Film Centre. 

She started her career as a music critic, writing for SPIN, The Village Voice and The Globe & Mail. She has directed numerous music videos for bands that include PUP and Jeremy Dutcher, earning two JUNO nominations.

In 2022, Levack's debut as a writer/director I LIKE MOVIES, premiered at TIFF in 2022. The film is a coming of age comedy and is based on her experiences working at Blockbuster Video in the early 2000's. It was named to TIFF’s annual year-end Canada’s Top Ten list for 2022 and won four awards at the Vancouver Film Critics Circle Awards 2022 (including best Film and best Screenplay). 

Chandler is currently in post on the Netflix/Happy Madison feature ROOMMATES, written by Jimmy Fowlie and Ceara O’Sullivan, and starring Sadie Sandler. Her second feature, MILE END KICKS, will premiere as the opening night film of TIFF's Special Presentations lineup this year. The film is based on Levack's experiences as a young female rock critic living in Montreal’s Mile End,  at the time when Grimes and Mac DeMarco were beginning their careers. It stars Barbie Ferreira, Jay Baruchel, Devon Bostick and Stanley Simons.

thumbnail.alt_text: See You When I See You

long_description: Grace Pine, a driven though easily distracted 23-year-old. She leaves her quirky parents’ home for a shared apartment found on Craigslist to devote herself to writing the next great book in the 33 1/3 album exploration series. Hers will be on the iconic Alanis Morissette opus Jagged Little Pill. Loft parties introduce Grace to two paramours. Unfortunately, they are members of the same rock band, Bone Patrol. And instead of sequestering herself away to complete her draft, she uses her music industry know-how to get in with the band as their publicist.Through wine-fuelled poetry readings and other ill-advised choices, Grace is in the trenches of self-discovery.

description: Please join us in welcoming the Texas High School Shorts to the SXSW EDU Film Program! This block of screenings will feature thirteen short films: “Just ask.” -- A boy fixates over asking a girl out at a subway station after recently being rejected.“The Cookie Quest” -- A young baker contracts an illness that stops her from being able to do what she loves. She struggles with her symptoms, eventually baking one cookie, beginning the transition back to her normal life.“Lyle in Love” -- Lyle must choose whether or not to ask out the girl whom he cherishes most.“Eclipse” -- The Sun is passing by the Moon. Remember to wear your sunglasses.“Wendigo” -- A lonely shapeshifter tries to make friends in a big forest.“She Follows Me” -- “She Follows Me” introduces Harper, a teenage girl struggling with depression who is contemplating suicide, until an unexpected visitor helps her rediscover a part of her life that she thought was gone forever.“Uno” -- When Derian cheats in a friendly game of Uno, his friend seeks revenge with the help of a magical Uno card. “Bear Bones” -- Bear Bones follows the surreal journey of a teddy bear.“DASH’D” -- A regular dude can't decide what to order on a food delivery app.“Operation Goliath” -- Two soldiers, Pat and Hank, are trapped behind enemy lines in a dense jungle, but a new threat is waiting in the darkness.“New Heights – with JD Wallace – New Heights follows Joshua” -- “JD” Wallace, a 6’5” Jack Yates High School senior whose rise as a student-athlete challenges every assumption about him—revealing that true elevation isn’t just about height, but speed, precision, discipline, and purpose.“Hot Off the Reel - with Ken Burns” -- As Jack Yates High School approaches its 100-year anniversary, four JY Cinema Dual Credit students step into the world of professional documentary filmmaking when they meet legendary filmmaker Ken Burns at Houston PBS. “Gambini Fights Lucheesy (TONY???) and the Lucheeses: The Movie” -- Two omnipotent mafia bosses engage in a fierce battle for the perfect croissant recipe.Following the final film, there will be a Q&A with the audience featuring the student filmmakers.

contributors.name: Suzy Robertson
contributors.title: Learning Design Expert
contributors.details: Suzy Robertson is a Learning Design Expert at McKinsey’s Design and Development Center of Excellence and a contributor to their Learning Research and Innovation Lab. Before transitioning into L&D, Suzy was a K–12 educator and is passionate about educational innovation and learning science. With a background in sociology and a love for the arts, she brings a creative and human-centered lens to learning design.

description:
Change keeps coming fast. Teams, educators, and leaders are being asked to adopt new tools, behaviors, and priorities at a relentless pace. But many change efforts fail to stick. People feel overwhelmed, disconnected, or left behind. Change does not fail because people resist it. It fails because of how we design and deliver it.
This session rethinks change through the lens of learning science. Drawing on research around metacognition, motivation, and cognitive load, we’ll explore why transformation stalls when people can’t see the relevance, can’t experiment safely, or simply can’t keep up.

contributors.details: Michelle Bedolla is a graduate of Johns Hopkins University and currently pursuing a doctorate at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign. With a strong foundation in edtech and startup innovation, Michelle has applied deep expertise in design thinking, systems thinking, and change management to guide organizations through complex challenges and innovative growth. As the founder of an edtech startup, Book Club Edition, Michelle continues to create new approaches to learning experiences.

description: The Baby-Sitters Club was a female-founded startup that thrived in the care economy, which included early-childhood education. This session highlights how the startup founders responded to local demand, built trust, and scaled their service with limited resources. Their fee-for-service business model provided affordable childcare to families. The Baby-Sitters Club incorporated empathy, social and emotional learning, creativity, and collaborative leadership into their core values. These business practices and values are transferable to startups in the real and modern world.

films.name: Winter Ceremony
films.description:
A long-divorced Chinese couple reunites in Texas for their daughter’s college graduation. 

The mother stays in the daughter’s small apartment, while the father returns each night to a hotel room of his own. The daughter drifts between her parents and her own thoughts. 

At times, they appear to be a family. 

After years of absence, what remains between them goes unspoken, as the father keeps his distance, lingering nearby.

films.description: The hottest summer on record left Austin ablaze and terrified, a city where heat hits hardest in at-risk neighborhoods and communities of color. In the aftermath, the Castañón family walks into the woods, asking: What is heat? At a city-run heat-mapping event, they trace invisible threats and exercise small acts of agency, exploring how conversation—at home, with neighbors, with scientists and policy-makers—shapes the way we live in a world remade by heat.

films.name: Stalin Boys
films.description: Four Mexican-American middle school boys in a Texas border town have developed an unusual obsession: Joseph Stalin. When their teacher tells them about the Texas State History Fair, they write a play about the Soviet dictator - and his efforts to destroy all who opposed him. As the boys write and rehearse their play about Stalin, they are forced to confront their own relationship with power and control.

films.name: Freedom At Stake
films.description: In Texas, new legislation aims to criminalize those who help others access abortion—even across state lines. This film follows a determined network of activists confronting the legal and financial risks of “aiding and abetting” abortion care. In the wake of a critical vote on the ballot, they push back against Prop A and the growing trend of punitive laws, revealing the emotional toll and the grassroots resistance that continues to hold strong in Texas. "Freedom At Stake", shines a light on the resistance to the escalating assault on abortion care and access in small-town Texas—and the sweeping national consequences could follow.
films.logline: Activists in Texas fight back against Prop A, a measure targeting those who help others seek abortions across state lines. As legal risks grow, so does their determination to protect access and bodily autonomy.

films.name: Forcefield of Love
films.description: Dan and Doris both find themselves single in their 70s after their spouses of decades have passed away. After using an online dating service during the pandemic for older singles, they talk on the phone for three months and fall in love before meeting in person. Now living in Austin, Texas, and married for three years, the two wear lavish matching outfits, go out dancing several nights a week, and have an active sexual life rooted in both fantasy and intimacy. With a deep awareness of their mortality guiding their choices, Dan and Doris are not afraid to show up in the world as their true selves, disregarding cultural norms for how older people should look, love, and move through the world.

name: Baby/Girls

contributors.name: Alyse Walsh
contributors.details: Alyse Walsh is an award-winning documentary filmmaker whose work spans multiple continents and genres. Recently she was a Director and Executive Producer of the Emmy-winning Season 2 of "Home," an Apple Original Documentary Series produced with A24. She directed several episodes of the Emmy-nominated Netflix science series "Connected." Alyse was the Supervising Producer of "Diagnosis," also for Netflix, as well as for "Defying Gravity," a PGA award-winning YouTube Original series about women’s gymnastics.

contributors.name: Jackie Jesko
contributors.details: Jackie Jesko is a director and journalist who seeks out stories about complicated people, places, and societies. Her most recent credits include "Barbara Walters Tell Me Everything" (Hulu, Tribeca Premiere 2025) and "Savior Complex" (HBO, 2023). Jackie’s work has been honored with several awards including a DuPont, an Emmy, and the James Foley Medal for Courage in Journalism. She is also a co-founder of Latchkey Films.

long_description: "Baby/Girls" is a verité documentary set in Arkansas that explores what teen motherhood looks like in post-Dobbs America. Filmed over two years with unprecedented access inside a Christian maternity home for pregnant teens, the film follows three young women as they carry their pregnancies, give birth, and adapt to their new realities. Through their stories, the film offers a rare, unfiltered portrait of life at the intersection of girlhood and motherhood in the American South.

long_description: In a world devastated by a contaminated water supply, Kai, a lost soul, finds herself living out of her car after a bad breakup. Each day is a struggle until fate intervenes and leads her to a hidden utopian lake, where the water is pure and life flourishes. At this secret haven, Kai encounters a band of eccentric misfits each with their own stories of loss and hope. Among them is Mallory, an enigmatic and wealthy pregnant woman living out an escapist fantasy. Despite their vastly different backgrounds, Kai and Mallory are drawn to each other, and a sudden, passionate romance ignites. As their bond deepens, Kai begins to uncover the layers of Mallory’s life and the secrets she harbors.

long_description:
On October 20, 1967, Roger Patterson captured 59 seconds of film showing a creature walking through the Northern California woods—footage that became the most analyzed and debated in history. Fifty-seven years later, a reel of 16mm film discovered in a safe changes everything.

"Capturing Bigfoot" reveals the untold story behind the world's greatest mystery, told for the first time by Patterson's own son and the people who were there.

This is a story about family legacy, broken friendships, and belief itself.
