films.description:
On October 20, 1967, Roger Patterson captured 59 seconds of film showing a creature walking through the Northern California woods—footage that became the most analyzed and debated in history. Fifty-seven years later, a reel of 16mm film discovered in a safe changes everything.

"Capturing Bigfoot" reveals the untold story behind the world's greatest mystery, told for the first time by Patterson's own son and the people who were there.

This is a story about family legacy, broken friendships, and belief itself.
films.logline: A reel of 16mm film locked away for over 50 years turns the Bigfoot debate on its head.
films.long_description:

name: Dead Deer High

contributors.name: Jo Rochelle
contributors.details: Jo Rochelle is a Jamaican-American screenwriter and filmmaker based in California, originally from Minneapolis. She attended New York University's Tisch School of the Arts as a Drama major, where she discovered her passion for writing and directing stories and hasn't stopped. She has written and directed award-winning short films and the feature film, “Jasmine is a Star” (streaming on FUSE+). Jo’s an alumnus of Teach for America where she taught 6th grade English and Social Studies in the Mississippi Delta. She was also a writer on seasons four and five of “Good Trouble” on Freeform/Hulu.

long_description: In the aftermath of a tragic shooting, a once-brilliant slam poetry team has lost their voice. Now, their English teacher must overcome his crippling fear of returning to the classroom to help them find healing through words on the stage.

name: "Bathe in Beats" Official Wellness Social Kickoff Party At SXSW 2026
long_description:
Bathe in Beats is an official SXSW Kickoff Wellness Social that blends music, nervous system optimization, art, and social connection into a half-day immersive experience that reflects the true pulse of Austin culture today.

As SXSW opens the city to creators, innovators, and cultural leaders from around the world, Bathe in Beats offers a radically different entry point into the week: not another party that burns people out, but a somatic, sensory, and social reset that fuels creativity, connection, and longevity.

This experience showcases how music, wellness, and culture are no longer separate worlds, they are colliding, collaborating, and reshaping how people gather.

name: Mentor Session: Greg Swan (FINN Partners)

contributors.name: Greg Swan
contributors.title: Senior Partner, Digital-Social-AI
contributors.details: Greg Swan is a senior marketing leader who blends experience with creative, digital and social advertising, content strategy, PR, and emerging technology for startups, Fortune 500 companies, and all sizes in between.He leads creative strategies and integrated marketing programs for brands rooted in consumer insights, social media, creative technology, PR, AI, content strategy, and the cultures that knit them together.In previous roles at Fallon, The Social Lights, space150, McCann, and Weber Shandwick, Greg led award-winning work for brands like Arby’s, Nike, Verizon, State Farm, US Army, General Mills, and The Coca-Cola Company.His teams built integrated marketing strategies for brands like Arby’s and State Farm, monetized trending topics for brands like Fruit Roll-Ups and Totino’s, built the social strategy for the U.S. Army and Nike Sportswear, launched the first Snapchat from outer space, the first Facebook 360o Super Bowl spot, the first tweet from the International Space Station, and introduced Snapchat Spectacles to pro sports.As a futurist, technologist, and national conference speaker, Greg is always looking for ways to take a more active role in defining and shaping the industry and future of creativity. This includes his roles on the South by Southwest Advisory Board, 4A's Social Media Committee, Shorty Awards, and more.Greg was named to PR Week’s 40 Under 40, Minneapolis-St. Paul's Business Journal’s 40 Under 40, and Social Media Professional of the Year by PR News.His teams' work has received multiple accolades and industry awards, including Cannes Lions, The Effies, The ADDY Awards, The Webby Awards, The Shorty Awards, Clio Awards, D&AD Awards, IABC Quills, PR Week Awards, SABRE Awards, PRSA Anvils, PR News Platinum Awards, AICP, and more.Ask him about his fax machine.

contributors.company: The Art and Science of Connection
contributors.name: Kasley Killam
contributors.title: Author
contributors.details: Kasley Killam is a leading expert in social health and author of The Art and Science of Connection: Why Social Health is the Missing Key to Living Longer, Healthier, and Happier. As a Harvard-trained social scientist, 2X TED speaker, sought-after advisor, and award-winning founder, Killam has been dedicated to improving well-being through human connection for nearly 15 years. Globally recognized for her thought leadership on social health, Killam’s collaborations with top organizations like Google, the US Department of Health and Human Services, and the World Economic Forum contribute to building more socially healthy products, workplaces, and communities. Discover her insights in outlets like The New York Times, Forbes, NPR, CNBC, and The Washington Post and join her newsletter community at www.kasleykillam.com.

description: Social health is today where mental health was 10-15 years ago—but we’ve reached a turning point. That was the bold claim from leading expert Kasley Killam in her SXSW 2025 opening keynote. This year, she’s back to reveal the most important breakthroughs, trends, and predictions shaping the rapidly growing movement to transform society through connection and community. Drawing on new research and cutting-edge innovation around the globe, Killam will surface surprising insights, the most promising opportunities for impact, and an inspiring vision of what’s next. No matter your industry, this is the session you can’t miss if you want to understand—and help lead—the future of relationships, longevity, and human thriving.

name: How To Meaningfully Connect in a World That Has Gone to Sh*t

contributors.name: Susan McPherson
contributors.title: Founder, CEO And Author
contributors.details: Susan McPherson is a serial connector, angel investor, and corporate responsibility expert. She is the founder and CEO of McPherson Strategies, a communications consultancy focused on the intersection of brands and social impact. She is the author of The Lost Art of Connecting (McGraw-Hill). Susan has 30+ years of experience in marketing, public relations, and sustainability communications, speaking regularly at industry events including Massachusetts Conference for Women, BSR, DLD, Worth Women and Techonomy, and contributing to the Harvard Business Review, Fast Company, and Forbes. She has appeared on NPR, CNN, USA Today, The New Yorker, New York Magazine and the Los Angeles Times.Susan is the recipient of Forbes magazine’s 50 over 50—Impact 2021 award and Worth Media’s Worthy100 award and serves on the boards of The 19th News and the US Chamber of Connection and serves as advisor to The Better Politics Foundation, LEBEC and The Conduit.

description:
We live in the most “connected” era in human history — and yet loneliness, burnout, and distrust are at historic highs. Convenience has replaced care. Algorithms now mediate our relationships. And many of us have quietly lost our ability to sit with difference, discomfort, and each other.

In this deeply human, and surprisingly hopeful keynote, McPherson explores how technology and current political strife have weakened our connection muscle, and why empathy and intentional friction are the missing ingredients in rebuilding trust, collaboration, and belonging. Drawing on two decades of work across corporations, nonprofits, and movements, Susan shares practical, actionable ways teams and leaders can foster genuine connection — online and in person — without adding more meetings, tools, or performative “culture” initiatives. This talk is a call to reconnect — not by opting out of technology, but by remembering how to be human with it.
long_description:
We live in the most “connected” era in human history — and yet loneliness, burnout, and distrust are at historic highs. Convenience has replaced care. Algorithms now mediate our relationships. And many of us have quietly lost our ability to sit with difference, discomfort, and each other.

In this deeply human, and surprisingly hopeful keynote, McPherson explores how technology and current political strife have weakened our connection muscle, and why empathy and intentional friction are the missing ingredients in rebuilding trust, collaboration, and belonging. Drawing on two decades of work across corporations, nonprofits, and movements, Susan shares practical, actionable ways teams and leaders can foster genuine connection — online and in person — without adding more meetings, tools, or performative “culture” initiatives. This talk is a call to reconnect — not by opting out of technology, but by remembering how to be human with it.

name: Beyond Borders: Diverse Alliances for Immigrant Wellbeing

contributors.name: Divya Chhabra
contributors.title: Program Director
contributors.details: Dr. Divya Chhabra is a child and adolescent psychiatrist, writer, and filmmaker. At Emma Bowen Center, she launched a trauma program for families with young children. A former teacher and tech professional, she blends storytelling, systems thinking, and mental health. She led statewide children’s policy at NYS OMH, consults and creates for award-winning shows on platforms like Nickelodeon and Spotify, and teaches at NYU. She’s held minority leadership roles in the APA and worked globally in mental health and humanitarian settings. She trained at UCSF, Columbia, and Cornell after graduating from Northwestern.

contributors.name: Tiffany Hernandez
contributors.title: Project Coordinator
contributors.details: Tiffany is a dedicated and mission-driven professional who has made a meaningful impact in communities through roles in program management, education, and patient navigation. Combining a strong background in public health with a passion for social equity, she has consistently worked to address barriers to healthcare, education, and community support services for underserved populations, particularly immigrant and Spanish-speaking communities. She has also partnered with LGBTQIA+ organizations to support inclusive programming, advocate for queer and trans rights, and ensure affirming, accessible care for LGBTQIA+ individuals—especially those at the intersection of immigrant identity.

name: How to Raise Changemakers: Lessons from Brazil’s Youth

contributors.name: Laura Bruscagin
contributors.title: Marketing Coordinator
contributors.details: Laura Bruscagin is a storyteller and Youth Communication Specialist based in Brazil. She works at the intersection of social impact, youth engagement, education, and civic leadership, using communication to foster empathy and inspire real-world action among young people. Laura has worked on social impact projects with partners such as the United Nations and Nexus Global, connecting underrepresented voices to global conversations on leadership and social responsibility. She led the Youth Volunteer Project delegation at the Nexus Global Summit, supporting Brazilian youth in sharing their perspectives on social change. As a young leader herself, Laura brings a peer-to-peer perspective to conversations on youth engagement, helping educators nurture the next generation of changemakers.

contributors.name: Ana Catharina Resende Quartiero
contributors.title: Student
contributors.details: Brazilian student studying abroad at UC Berkeley, passionate about community building and the power of education. Began her journey in service with Turma do Jiló’s Youth Volunteer Project and has dedicated over 8 years to volunteer work. She currently serves as President of the Brazilian Student Association and volunteers with Creative, a student group that teaches art in underserved communities. As CFO of Brazil at Silicon Valley and with three internships in Investment Banking, she brings a strong commitment to advancing Latin American companies on a global stage. With academic training in Applied Mathematics and Economics and a minor in Data Science, she seeks to bridge quantitative insight with social impact using finance, data, and education to build a more inclusive future.

contributors.name: Maria Luiza Comar Gayotto
contributors.title: Student
contributors.details: Luiza Gayotto is a Brazilian youth activist and International Relations scholar focused on Peace & Justice. She has been a volunteer in Turma do Jiló’s project “Voluntariado da Turma do Jiló” since 2017 and worked as an ambassador for Gerando Falcões International’s “Connecting Realities” program. Luiza is the founder of MandaLuz, an art-therapy initiative, and has led projects supporting girls’ education and youth leadership. As a multilingual advocate and student abroad, she bridges local action and global dialogue to create opportunities for future generations to make a difference.

contributors.name: Carolina Videira
contributors.title: CEO
contributors.details: Carolina is a Social Entrepreneur and Consultant specialized in Inclusive Education, Human Rights, and ESG. She holds a Master’s in Behavioral Neuroscience from UNIFESP and postgraduate degrees in Diversity Management, Inclusive Practices, and Behavioral Neuroscience. She is an Ashoka Fellow, founder and CEO of Turma do Jiló. Carolina serves on the UN Brazil Human Rights Council and coordinates Diversity Inclusion postgraduate studies at Instituto Singularidades. With over 20 years in corporate sectors, she has received the 2022 Social Entrepreneur of the Year Award and the UN Women USA Rise and Raise Others Award for reducing inequalities. She advises Instituto da Oportunidade Social and the UN Educa 2030 Movement, supporting inclusive education aligned with the UN 2030 Agenda.

name: It Takes a Region: Cybersecurity Pathways in Rural Alabama

image.alt_text: It Takes a Region: Cybersecurity Pathways in Rural Alabama

contributors.name: Kim Knight
contributors.title: Career and Technical Education Director
contributors.details: Kim V. Knight, NBCT, is the Career and Technical Education Director for Talladega County Schools, where she leads innovative, industry-driven workforce development programs for high school and middle grades students. With more than 20 years of experience in education, she is recognized for building sustained, successful grant initiatives that continuously expand career pathways in construction trades, cybersecurity, health sciences, manufacturing, and work-based learning. A National Board Certified Teacher with a master’s degree in Educational Leadership from the University of Alabama at Birmingham, Kim is a frequent state and regional conference presenter known for translating grant opportunities into scalable, student-centered programs through strong industry and community partnerships. She has served on the Governor's Alabama Attainment Committee and other workforce advisory boards, advocating for real-world learning that prepares students for immediate workforce success.

contributors.name: Scott Ross
contributors.title: Director of Information Technology
contributors.details: Scott Ross is a leading technology and cybersecurity expert in Alabama. Growing up in Huntsville, AL he developed early computer skills and began working in the field as a teen. After earning a Bachelor of Information Systems Management from Auburn University, he returned to Huntsville in 2010. His career started in the defense industry with the Army Space and Missile Defense Command (SMDC) and Army Material Command (AMC), where he quickly became a key advisor. In 2012, Scott transitioned to Parsons Corporation, leading IT Operations and Cybersecurity teams across various sectors. By 2019, he became the Director of IT at the HudsonAlpha Institute for Biotechnology, addressing cybersecurity challenges in genomics. He received the 2021 InspireCIO Orbie award for Alabama CIO of the Year for Nonprofit/Public Sector Finalists. Scott holds a CISSP certification and is a principal investigator on genomic data cybersecurity research with UAH CCRE and NIST NCCOE. Additionally, he actively promotes STEM education and serves on the Alabama CIO Advisory Board and the Alabama STEM Foundation's Board of Directors.

contributors.name: Seth Walker
contributors.title: Alumnus
contributors.details: Seth Walker is a 2025 graduate of Lincoln High School in Alabama and a cybersecurity major at Troy University. In 2023, Seth and his peers actively helped launch Talladega County’s first Cybersecurity Pathways program in partnership with Digital Promise, supporting the Region 2 site visit and raising awareness throughout the district about the value of the initiative for students. Driven by a passion for learning and teaching critical cybersecurity concepts, Seth chose this career path to empower others to understand and protect digital systems. His dream job is to become a cyber auditor, ensuring companies maintain proper security protocols and safeguard community data integrity.

contributors.name: Kimberly Smith
contributors.title: Chief Innovation Officer
contributors.details: Kimberly Smith is Chief Inclusive Innovation Officer at Digital Promise’s Center for Inclusive Innovation. She leads partnerships with school district leaders and their communities to co-research and co-design solutions that help every learner grow and thrive. She has held leadership roles at the Network for Teaching Entrepreneurship, PBS, Discovery Education, and CPB, advancing education technology and learner-centered models. An Aspen-Pahara Fellow and co-founder of the National Charter Collaborative, she holds an MBA from Johns Hopkins and a BS in Journalism from the University of Colorado. She serves on the boards of Beacon House, CatalystED, the Learner Centered Collaborative, and the National Charter Collaborative.

This session shares how a regional alliance is designing hands-on learning experiences, embedding aligned credentials, and unlocking high-wage, high-demand careers for students. Discover how a rural community is transforming opportunity through workforce-aligned education and community-wide vision.
sort: IT TAKES A REGION: CYBERSECURITY PATHWAYS IN RURAL ALABAMA

contributors.name: Lori Baker
contributors.title: Executive Vice President for Global Strategy & Programs
contributors.details: Dr. Lori Baker is Executive Vice President for Global Strategy and Programs at Belmont University, where she leads innovative global education initiatives at the intersection of science, culture, and social impact. An internationally recognized forensic anthropologist and Fellow of the American Academy of Forensic Sciences, she founded the award-winning Reuniting Families program addressing humanitarian and human rights challenges worldwide. Dr. Baker has advised governments across the globe, and her work has been featured by National Geographic, NPR, BBC, and other international media outlets.

contributors.name: Alexey Steblev
contributors.title: Chief Creative Officer, Board Member
contributors.details:
Alexey Steblev is a cellist, composer, educator, entrepreneur, and cultural leader. Trained at the Gnessin School and the Moscow Conservatory, he gained international recognition as a member of the Moscow Quartet and a soloist with the chamber orchestra Moscow Virtuosi. He later co-founded the New Russian Quartet. He has taught at the State Classical Academy Maimonides and has composed music for theater and film.
As an entrepreneur, Alexey co-founded several startups and has been active in venture investments. He founded Way2Art.club, a platform promoting art and culture. He is a co-founder, Chief Creative Officer, and Board member of the CultTech Association in Vienna, leading efforts to merge art with emerging technologies.

This interactive Meet Up focuses on non-linear, learner-driven approaches where technology acts as a creative collaborator—not a skill to master. name: Higher Ed Needs Caring & Liberatory Leadership to Thrive

contributors.name: Kevin Mcclure
contributors.title: Department Chair and Professor
contributors.details: Dr. Kevin R. McClure is a Professor of Higher Education and Chair of the Department of Educational Leadership at the University of North Carolina Wilmington. He also serves as Co-Director of the Alliance for Research on Regional Colleges. Kevin’s public scholarship covers a range of topics, and throughout the pandemic he wrote viral articles on morale, burnout, disengagement, staffing, and leadership in higher education. He is now a regular columnist at The Chronicle of Higher Education, writing the Working Better column on the higher education workplace.

contributors.name: Annmarie Caño
contributors.title: Professor
contributors.details: Dr. Annmarie Caño is a professor of psychology at Gonzaga University, a licensed clinical psychologist, and a certified coach to higher education leaders. Her writing is informed by her lived experience as a Latina and first-generation college student with over 25 years of experience in higher education. Annmarie is an award-winning teacher, mentor, and researcher and a two-time Fellow of the American Psychological Association who has served in leadership roles at public and private institutions. You can find her articles with practical advice about leadership and liberatory practice online at Inside Higher Ed and HigherEdJobs.

Namely, staff, faculty, and leaders are invited to engage in systemic and structural changes aligned with liberation praxis and the ethics of care. Drawing from organizational theories, the social sciences, research, and lived experience, the discussants will challenge each other and the audience to imagine the personal and institutional changes required to promote employee well-being and creativity in today’s higher education workplace.

Attiah often writes on issues relating to race, gender and international politics, with a special interest in Africa. Previously, she reported as a freelancer for the Associated Press while based in the Caribbean. Attiah was the winner of the 2019 George Polk Award and was the 2019 Journalist of the Year from the National Association of Black Journalists

contributors.title: Host & Creator
contributors.details: She has collaborated with organizations and community stakeholders to promote social justice, equity, and inclusion in over 20 countries, including on a global treaty adopted by the United Nations. For over a decade, she has worked professionally on both local and global levels to create an equitable world by centering on those who are most marginalized. As Senior Program Officer at the Solidarity Center, she collaborated with global labor organizations to promote inclusive development and to advocate for human rights and gender equality.

contributors.name: Gabriel Yanagihara
contributors.title: Emerging Technology Teacher
contributors.details: Gabriel Yanagihara is a classroom teacher, AI literacy consultant, and curriculum designer based in Honolulu, Hawaii. He teaches middle school game design, AI tools, and emerging technology at ‘Iolani School, and has trained thousands of educators across Hawaii on how to use AI in student-centered, culturally grounded ways. Gabriel is the founder of the Digital Literacy Ambassadors program and the author of Teaching Joy. His work spans K–12, community outreach, and nonprofit consulting, with a focus on making AI literacy accessible, joyful, and low-cost. He is also an esports coach, workshop leader, and public speaker on AI in education and workforce development.

description: While most schools banned AI when it first emerged, one school in Hawai‘i saw the wave coming and started paddling early. As the emerging technology teacher at ‘Iolani School, my goal was to make every mistake as quickly as possible so that we can learn valuable lessons together. We knew from day one that AI was here to stay, so while others watched from shore, my students and I were wiping out, experimenting, and figuring it out together. This session shares the stories from those chaotic early days and how they led to the AI literacy programs we’ve built in Hawai‘i today.

This session shares the stories from those chaotic early days and how they led to the AI literacy programs we’ve built in Hawai‘i today.

name: The Future is Low-Tech: Lessons from the Early 2000s

contributors.name: Jésabel DC
contributors.title: Queer Futurist | Tech Anthropologist | EdTech Founder
contributors.details:
Jésabel DC is a queer futurist reclaiming technology as a tool for care, learning and collective autonomy.

Her work explores how digital systems shape the human experience. Through gamified workshops and consulting, she works with individuals and organizations who want to rethink their relationship to technology.

She’s also developing The Lifestyle Lab, a low-tech, nervous system-friendly video game that teaches life and civic skills through real-world interaction. It serves as a prototype for what non-extractive, human-centered tech can look like.

description:
Let's rewind back to the early 2000s – slower interfaces, finite gameplay, loading bars, shared family computers and digital experiences that rewarded patience, curiosity and real-world interaction.

In this talk, we'll unpack the overlooked design features of the era and explore how they can be applied today.

This session is for designers, educators, technologists and decision-makers who want to take part in building a low-tech future!

contributors.name: Lisa Varga
contributors.title: Associate Executive Director, Public Policy And Advocacy
contributors.details: Lisa R. Varga is the Associate Executive Director of Public Policy & Advocacy at the American Library Association’s Washington Office. In 2024, she was named Library Journal’s Librarian of the Year. Prior to her work at ALA, Lisa had spent 15 years as the Executive Director of the Virginia Library Association, and speaks nationally on a variety of topics, including Intellectual Freedom.

contributors.name: Maya Chupkov
contributors.title: Media & Democracy Program Manager
contributors.details:
Maya Chupkov is a filmmaker and public-interest policy
strategist whose work bridges community-rooted storytelling,
disability advocacy, and democracy reform. Across film, audio,
writing, and policy, she advances ideas that touch on the
underrepresented voices in the speech diversity communities. In
addition to overseeing the media policy program at California Common
Cause, she is working on a documentary that intersects with
stuttering, race, and the Deep South, and follows Issac Bailey, a
black man with a severe stutter from St. Stephen, South Carolina.

contributors.name: Erin Harkey
contributors.title: Executive Director
contributors.details: Erin Harkey has over 20+ years experience helping individuals and communities succeed through the arts. Erin was the Commissioner of the Chicago Department of Cultural Affairs and Special Events (DCASE). Harkey served the City of Chicago as Projects Administrator, then Deputy Commissioner for Programming and First Deputy Commissioner. In her dual role as Senior Policy Advisor for Arts in Culture in the Mayor’s Office, she advised on cultural policy and arts strategy across all City departments and agencies. She previously managed public art programs at Los Angeles County Arts Commission and the Arts Council for Long Beach. Harkey holds two master’s degrees in Public Art Administration and Urban Planning from the University of Southern California (USC) and a bachelor’s degree in Marketing from Howard University.

contributors.name: Jax Deluca
contributors.title: Executive Director
contributors.details:
Jax Deluca is a cultural strategist with over two decades of leadership across public service and nonprofit arts organizations. Currently, she is the interim director for the Future Film Coalition, advocating for the independent film sector by uniting independent film professionals and organizations to build collective power and shape field-wide efforts to secure visibility, resources, and public policy protections that will fortify the independent ecosystem and ensure audiences benefit from a diverse and thriving cultural landscape for generations to come. 

In her previous role as the Director of Film & Media Arts at the National Endowment for the Arts (2016–2025), she oversaw a federal funding portfolio, spearheaded national initiatives, such as the Independent Media Arts Group (IMAG) in partnership with Sundance Institute and BAVC Media, and produced research offering critical insights into field-wide infrastructure needs, creative technology practices, and high-level challenges facing the independent film ecosystem. She is a 2025-26 Documentary Film in the Public Interest Fellow at the Harvard Kennedy School’s Shorenstein Center on Media, Politics and Public Policy.

He has partnered with JPMorgan, Harvard Business School, SXSW, Google, Pepsi, Meta, and more. In May 2023, he hosted a conversation with Vice President Harris at The White House Forum for AANHPIs. contributors.details:
Andrew enjoys saying the quiet parts out loud. 

Regardless of what consumers state they need, want, and desire, he is  in the business of vocalizing the unspoken nuances of what they do when no one is looking. He discovers consumers' true behaviors, values, and perceptions with help from a dynamic toolset including behavioral economics, ethnography, and data science. 

Andrew love exploring data and telling engaging stories that blend the best of quantitative and qualitative methods into actionable insights. Eager to engage in spirited debates, he thrive on challenging the status quo.

name: Future Tense: A Vibecoding Experience for Educators

contributors.name: Miriam Schneider
contributors.title: Director of Learning Initiatives
contributors.details: Miriam Schneider is a trusted leader with two decades of experience in edtech, building products and programs at the intersection of cutting edge technology and educational impact. She currently serves as the Director of Learning Initiatives at Google DeepMind, where she leads efforts to explore how the future of AI can help advance and augment teaching, learning and human development. She’s deeply committed to cultivating collaboration across the broader education ecosystem to ensure that AI is grounded in learning science, built responsibly, researched rigorously, distributed equitably and fosters durable outcomes. Miriam’s fingerprints are etched throughout Google’s history in learning and education. During her tenure, she has built and led high-performing marketing and strategy teams across the company’s broad portfolio of education products, including Google Classroom and Chromebooks. She has been a foundational architect of Google’s holistic approach to education, dating back to the company’s early days roadtripping to college campuses in an iconic 1970s biodiesel school bus. More recently, she introduced LearnLM — the world’s most pedagogical AI — and has helped establish global advisory boards, student-focused programs, and communities of practice to enhance engagement with leading industry experts, practitioners and learners. Miriam is known for her unwavering passion for her work, innate desire to elevate and celebrate educators, and steadfast belief that everyone deserves access to high quality learning experiences. She believes the world runs on relationships and that curiosity is our currency of connection. She is an avid crafter (letterpress and calligraphy), active mother (to Poppy and Owen), podcast enthusiast (welcomes all recommendations!) who tries to forest bathe as much as possible. She graduated Summa Cum Laude and Phi Beta Kappa from UCLA and studied French at the Sorbonne.

contributors.name: Alex Kotran
contributors.title: Founder & CEO
contributors.details: Alex Kotran is the CEO & Founder of aiEDU, a non-profit ensuring K12 students are ready for the age of AI. Alex has a decade of experience in the AI space. Before founding aiEDU in 2019 , he launched the social impact arm of H5, pioneering language models in the legal sector , and worked at Opower, an early ML clean tech company. A former Obama Administration appointee under HHS Secretary Sylvia Burwell, Alex bridges the gap between high-level policy and technical implementation. He previously organized AI Governance summits with UNESCO, Stanford Law, and the European Commission. He founded aiEDU to address the AI education gap he witnessed in his hometown of Akron, Ohio.

description: After 3+ years of AI panels and predictions, most people still haven't experienced the technology in a way that makes the stakes visceral. This hands-on workshop changes that. Participants will "vibe code"—building functional software through conversation with AI, no technical background required. You'll create your first learning tool in 10 minutes, iterate with peers, and leave with a working prototype. We'll close by exploring what this means for the future of learning and the future of work: What happens when anyone can build software? What skills matter when routine tasks get automated? Less philosophizing, more co-creating.

image.credit: Stefanie Zingsheim, the University of Sydney

contributors.details:
Dr Kai Riemer works with boards and executives to bring foresight expertise and deep understanding of emerging technologies into strategy and leadership.
He specialises in digital technology, artificial intelligence, the future of work, leadership and skills, and the management of change and transformation. He has shared his thinking and insights on these areas with audiences across the globe.
Kai is Professor of Information Technology and Organisation at the University of Sydney Business School. Alongside Dr Sandra Peter, he’s the Co-Director of Sydney Executive Plus (SE+), which focuses on digital-first leadership development. contributors.details:
Dr Sandra Peter leads executive and leadership development in cutting-edge areas of business, technology, and society.  She has spoken around the world and been told that she should do stand-up (be warned: some of her presentations contain AI-generated cats). 
As an Associate Professor at the University of Sydney Business School and Co-Director of Sydney Executive Plus (SE+), Sandra spends her time thinking about the future, researching the future, consulting on the future, and speaking about the future.
Alongside Dr Kai Riemer, she heads Sydney Executive Plus (SE+), which focuses on preparing leaders for what comes next. So far, SE+ has helped upskill executives and leaders across 20+ industries in areas ranging from AI Fluency to Geopolitics and Business to Net Zero.

contributors.name: Simon Wood
contributors.title: Director
contributors.details: Simon Wood is an Emmy nominated filmmaker based in Cape Town, South Africa. Wood’s films have screened at the worlds largest film festivals and won numerous awards in Africa, Asia, Europe and North America.

contributors.name: Rashin Fahandej
contributors.title: Director
contributors.details:
Rashin Fahandej is an Iranian-American immersive filmmaker, futurist, and cultural activist. Her artistic initiatives are multiyear experimental laboratories for collective radical reimaginations of social systems and future imaginaries. Fahandej's methodology, rooted in her “Art as Ecosystem” concept, leverages emerging technology and community co-creation through cross-sector collaborations, positioning artistic processes as catalysts for societal transformation. Her work has been exhibited at the Institute of Contemporary Art Boston, Ars Electronica, and Tribeca, as well as in civic spaces.
She is the recipient of the Prix Ars Electronica Festival, the Foster Prize at the Institute of Contemporary Art Boston, the Boston Mayor’s Office of Arts and Culture AIR program, MacDowell and more.

contributors.name: Nadav Assor
contributors.title: Director
contributors.details:
Nadav Assor’s work has been featured in film festivals, museums, galleries, and live venues across North America, Europe, and Asia. Recent venues include Vienna Art Week, Gallery 400 Chicago, Arsenal Berlin, the Oberhausen Film Festival, Video Vortex XI at Kochi-Muziris, India, Hong-Gah Museum Taipei, La Casa Encendida Madrid, Edith-Russ Haus Oldenburg, Transmediale Festival Berlin, the Soundwave Biennial San Francisco, Residency Unlimited NYC, and more. 

Assor’s work has been reviewed in publications such as Artforum, Hyperallergic, the Chicago Tribune, Art Monthly UK, and others  

Assor is an alumni fellow of the MIT Open Documentary Lab, where together with Tirtza Even he developed the immersive, feature-length, immigration-focused project “Chronicle of Fall”.

description: This interactive workshop explores how augmented reality (AR) can be used as a pedagogical tool to deepen learners’ relationships to place, memory, and community. Drawing from Layers of Place: Austin—a collection of six location-based AR artworks—participants will engage with artists’ approaches to place-based storytelling, public history, and experiential learning. Through discussion, short activities, and case studies, the session examines how AR can function as a method for cultivating attention, care, and critical engagement with the spaces we inhabit.

Drawing from Layers of Place: Austin—a collection of six location-based AR artworks—participants will engage with artists’ approaches to place-based storytelling, public history, and experiential learning. Through discussion, short activities, and case studies, the session examines how AR can function as a method for cultivating attention, care, and critical engagement with the spaces we inhabit.

name: Building AI Pathways for HBCU Talent & Community Impact

contributors.name: Stephen "Dr" Love
contributors.title: Producer
contributors.details: Stephen “Dr.” Love is an award-winning film and advertising producer and the founder of Made With Love Media. A graduate of Morehouse College and USC’s Peter Stark Producing Program, he has produced acclaimed films including The Land and They Cloned Tyrone, as well as culturally impactful advertising such as P&G’s Emmy-winning The Talk. His work centers storytelling, creativity, and authentic representation across media.

contributors.name: Meme Styles
contributors.title: President
contributors.details: Meme Styles is a nationally recognized AI ethics leader, social impact executive, and founder of Measure, a nonprofit focused on community-led data governance and equitable technology. She is Chair of the HBCU AI Conference & Training Summit and Vice President of Responsible & Ethical AI at the Austin AI Alliance. Meme’s work centers on interrogating bias in AI systems through participatory design, evaluation, and policy-informed practice. She advises institutions, funders, and technologists on aligning AI innovation with community accountability, workforce access, and long-term social impact.

contributors.name: Julian Thompson
contributors.title: Senior Director of Strategy Development
contributors.details: Julian Thompson is Senior Director of Strategy Development at the UNCF Institute for Capacity Building, where he leads initiatives that strengthen the long-term sustainability, leadership, and institutional effectiveness of HBCUs. His work focuses on strategy alignment, data-informed decision-making, and cross-sector collaboration to advance student success and organizational resilience across the HBCU ecosystem.

contributors.name: Chris Hyams
contributors.title: Chairman of the HBCU AiCon26
contributors.details: Chris Hyams is a technology executive, educator, and innovator focused on the intersection of workforce development, education, and emerging technology. As former CEO of Indeed, he led global efforts to expand equitable access to opportunity through data-driven hiring, skills-based pathways, and responsible AI. His work emphasizes aligning technology with human potential and inclusive economic mobility.

name: Cultural Conquest: The Digital Black American Blueprint

contributors.name: Shalom Miller
contributors.title: Founder
contributors.details:
Shalom “J.Storm” Miller is a renowned American music producer, songwriter, and manager with a career spanning pop, R&B, and hip-hop. He has collaborated with major artists like Beyoncé, Missy Elliott, and Gwen Stefani, earning six Grammy nominations and one win. Miller’s notable projects include Beyoncé’s Dangerously in Love and Stefani’s Love. Angel. Music. Baby. He was also signed to Missy Elliott’s label, The Goldmind Inc., from 2003 to 2007.
Miller is also the founder of Power Move Management Group and Power Move Education & Development Group, which supports emerging talent and music education. He serves as a Recording Academy voting member, NAACP Education Chair, and mentor with Grammy U and Berklee College of Music.

description: In the age of algorithms and automation, what does it mean to protect the essence of Black creativity? This session traces how the history of cultural appropriation is now mirrored through digital platforms, machine learning, and AI-generated content. Grammy-winning producer and strategist Shalom J. Storm Miller presents a future-facing blueprint for cultural integrity, offering educators, creatives, and technologists a framework for sustaining Black influence in an increasingly synthetic world.

description: Traditional differentiation is dead. Every child can grow—if given the chance. But too many neurodivergent students disengage when teachers lack the tools to adapt. With limited budgets and rising classroom complexity, we need a shift: inclusive education must become the standard, not the specialist’s job. This session challenges old models and showcases bold, realistic ways to embed adaptive teaching, reward innovation, and empower every educator—without asking for more time or money, just better thinking.

name: I Love Boosters

contributors.name: Boots Riley
contributors.details: Boots Riley is a walking contradiction like bullets and love mixin. Slurs his words with perfect diction, he's guilty of his convictions. Complicated compositions, punctuated propositions, it's tenacious two-stops, cinema with ambition. Make you rev your transmission, in the intersection twistin- when the Henny hits the ground, sidewalks will be christened. He's so nervous and sweaty, that the gat might slip out his hand. A homeless dude need a tip in his can (he put his bid in this, man. Now it's just bitterness, man). We need a bid-ness plan [a plan on how to change our economic system] , he's not just spittin at fans. When he's runnin from the police, he don't have to rush- he's so dope he just jumps in the toilet and flush. We cut it, boil it and hush, aluminum foil it and such- tryin to catch the few bucks, the big boys didn't clutch. We use the tweezers for crutch, when we done burned down the dutch, but when they Starsky & Hutch, we just shit out of luck.

name: Time and Water

image.credit: Archival Materials Courtesy of Andri Snær Magnason

contributors.name: Sara Dosa
contributors.details: Sara Dosa is an Oscar®-nominated nonfiction filmmaker whose work centers on the human relationship with more-than-human nature. The films she has directed, “Fire of Love” (2022), “The Seer & The Unseen” (2019) and “The Last Season” (2015), have won numerous awards, including a Peabody and the Directors’ Guild of America Award, and were nominated for over 40 awards, including an Academy Award, BAFTA, Emmy and an Independent Spirit Award. Dosa’s work has been shown at festivals worldwide, including Sundance, SXSW, New Directors/New Films, CPH:DOX and Visions du Réel, and has screened in partnership with museums such as the MOMA, BAMPFA and the Louvre. In 2018, Dosa was named to the inaugural class of DOCNYC’s “40 under 40” and inducted into the Academy of Motion Pictures’ documentary branch. She graduated from Wesleyan University with a double major in sociology and anthropology and has a joint master’s in anthropology and international development studies from the London School of Economics and Political Science. Dosa lives and works in California.

events.name: The Oldest Person in the World

image.alt_text: The Oldest Person in the World

thumbnail.alt_text: The Oldest Person in the World

long_description: Renowned Icelandic poet and author Andri Snær Magnason is chasing something elusive. As the glacial ice of his homeland melts, he constructs a cinematic time capsule to hold onto this moment and send it to the future, before everything he loves slips away. Using his own collected archives, his grandparents’ photographs, and films, as well as traditional songs and folktales, Andri interlaces his family’s story with that of the land around him. From Academy Award®-nominated director Sara Dosa, "Time and Water" is a universal reflection on the power of home and what it means to be alive amid profound epochal change.

name: First They Came for My College

image.alt_text: First They Came for My College

contributors.name: Patrick Bresnan
contributors.details: Using precise and illustrative cinematic images, Patrick Bresnan makes intimate films that counter the mythic concepts of America. Working with Ivete Lucas his features and shorts have premiere at Berlin, Sundance, The Quinzaine, Toronto, SXSW and T/F. In addition to making films he has served on the boards of experimental theaters and affordable housing non profits.

image.alt_text: I Got Bombed at Harvey's (aka 1,000 Pounds of Dynamite)

thumbnail.alt_text: I Got Bombed at Harvey's (aka 1,000 Pounds of Dynamite)

long_description: On January 6, 2023, Republican Governor Ron DeSantis enacted a right-wing takeover of a public university called New College of Florida, targeting both its culture and unique academic program for an ultra-conservative makeover. Resistance is immediate, but the campus descends into chaos as powerful political actors make sweeping changes. Caught up in the mix are a group of intellectually curious young people from all sides of the political spectrum intent on completing their studies at New College, which has suddenly become ground zero in the culture wars.
sort: FIRST THEY CAME FOR MY COLLEGE

name: Joybubbles

contributors.name: Rachael J Morrison
contributors.details: Rachael Morrison is a documentary filmmaker and archival producer. Her short documentary, "Elvers," premiered at the 2019 Camden International Film Festival and is featured online as part of The Atlantic Selects. She has worked as an archival producer on documentary series and feature films for HBO, Hulu, Netflix, Paramount Plus, and FX. "Joybubbles" is her feature-length directorial debut.

name: #Skyking

contributors.name: Patricia E. Gillespie
contributors.details:
Patricia E. Gillespie is the daughter of a cable splicer and a seamstress. As a filmmaker, she is preoccupied with character-driven explorations of underdogs and outsiders. With her narrative-leaning sensibilities, Gillespie has a proven track record of engaging broad audiences around stories that matter, particularly those relating to social class, public health, and the justice system. 

Her directorial work includes "The Secrets We Bury" and "They Called Him Mostly Harmless," both of which hit #1 on HBO Max, and "The Fire That Took Her," which won the 2023 News & Documentary Emmy for Outstanding Crime and Justice Documentary. She also created, directed, and executive produced Viceland’s highly rated first foray into serialized true crime, "The Devil You Know."

In addition to directing, Patricia also produces. Her credits include the Emmy-nominated, Oscar-shortlisted Sundance hit "Unrest"; Peabody-nominated "Whose Streets?"; and Oscar-nominated Robert Stone’s "Taken Hostage." 

She is a proud resident of NYC’s best borough, Queens, where she lives with her dog, Hank, and her husband, Alvaro.

long_description: #Skyking tells the story of 28-year-old Horizon Air ground service agent Richard “Beebo” Russell, who, to the shock of all who knew him, clocked into work wearing a shirt that said “the sky's no limit,” stole a 33-million-dollar plane, and took off into the skies of the Pacific Northwest—embarking on a white-knuckle flight that would come to embody the hopes, dreams, and despair of the American working class, and offer a timely look into the U.S. mental health crisis.

long_description:
Kayla Bachman, an author who struggles with emotional connection, Zach Bachman, a lawyer who dreams of being a folk singer and Wes Bachman, a graphic novelist / gambling & pill addict, meet to discuss their younger sister Scarlett who joined a cult in Kentucky. 
Zach and his dysfunctional and absent parents have hired cult deprogrammer Rick Delacroix to help them rescue Scarlett. 
They embark on a roadtrip to save their sister, and bring their family together.

events.name: Seahorse

long_description:
Cleo is new to Sparks, Nevada when she discovers a cigarette vending machine that inexplicably produces a book on Jean-Luc Godard. When she meets the Crop soon after, Cleo’s morphed into a cinephile, and when she learns of the Crop’s reservoir visits, she’s certain that she could time travel and meet Godard in 60s Paris.	

Crop leader Antoine is enamored with Cleo but rankled by her insinuations that Crop life is boring. When Cleo disappears at the reservoir, Antoine calls into question his own sense of purpose, before unexpected adventures materialize—a shootout, a dreamy gay barbecue—until Cleo returns to Sparks and the Crop must figure out where she’s been and if she’s lost her mind.

name: Ugly Cry

contributors.name: Emily Robinson
contributors.details:
Emily Robinson is a writer, director, and SAG Award-nominated, Special Drama Desk Award-winning actor known for her work in "Eight Grade", "The Year Between", "Private Life", "Edge of Everything", and "Transparent".

She is thrilled that her directorial debut feature film, "Ugly Cry", is making its premiere here at SXSW. Her short films have screened at numerous festivals, such as LA Film Festival, Outfest, and Frameline.  

Her debut novel, "Consumed", was published in 2023. 

Robinson holds a B.A. in Creative Writing from Columbia University.

events.name: My Brother's Killer

image.alt_text: Small Town Boys: The Murder of Billy London

thumbnail.alt_text: Small Town Boys: The Murder of Billy London

long_description: When Delaney's boyfriend leaves town to shoot a splashy zombie movie, she becomes obsessed with a character she’s auditioning for after she learns the producers think she has an "ugly cry." But when she tries to make her cry prettier, her performance suffers. Can she contort herself, and her face, to have the perfect cry? Her attempts to change herself cause Young Delaney to haunt her, catapulting present day Delaney deeper down the rabbit hole. She isolates herself and grows increasingly delusional, and interested in physical fixes to her acting problem. How can she make the world see her as she sees herself? How can she become and become and become? She will become famous. Or die trying.

name: One Another

contributors.name: Amber Love
contributors.details: Amber is a filmmaker and documentary editor based in Chicago, IL whose films explore intimate bonds and how we build futures together. Her work has been supported by PBS, HBO, IF/Then, The Gotham, NeXt Doc, and Short of the Week as well as screened at festivals including Doc 10 and Camden International Film Festival. Her most recent short film, “Lifetimes,” was funded by Firelight Films' Homegrown: Future Visions initiative and is available through PBS Digital. She has been a 2023 HBO/Gotham Diversity Development Fellow and a 2020 Sundance Art of Editing Fellow. One Another is her debut feature.

events.name: Agridulce (Bittersweet)

long_description: Sometimes it takes the end of something to know what is really at stake. Joe, Giorgia, and Lorri are all grappling with the possible end of an intimate friendship at vastly different stages of life: a cross-country move, a mental health crisis, and a shift into empty-nesting have forced them each to reevaluate the support they need from those closest to them. Chronicling three different friendships over the course of three years, "One Another" brings together verite with a wealth of personal archives to intertwine their journeys as they search for what it really means for us to care for each other. The result is a story of change, heartache, and connection in this ode to platonic love.

name: Caleb De Casper

contributors.name: Caleb De Casper
contributors.artist_connection: Label Management, Brand Partnership, Gear Endorsement, Distribution - US, Distribution - Worldwide, Other Artists to Tour With, Booking Agent - US, Booking Agent - UK/Europe, PR/Publicity Agency, Sync/Music Supervisors
contributors.details: From the horror cabaret and glam-rock theatrics of his early career to the shadowy, neon-lit world of his current dark synth-pop, Austin-based performer Caleb De Casper has never stopped evolving. A classically trained pianist and vocalist, De Casper commands the stage with a sharpened, unmistakable intensity — trading in the avant-garde gowns and stilettos of the past for a bold, more masculine and unfiltered presence that puts the focus squarely on the music, the message, and the electricity of performance. His 2022 debut LP Femme Boy expanded his sonic world, weaving dancefloor heat, cinematic drama, and queer storytelling into a record that was equal parts brooding and explosive. That same year, the City of Austin proclaimed Caleb De Casper Day, recognizing his cultural impact. He went on to perform yearly at SXSW, Austin City Limits Music Festival, Utopia Fest, Houston’s Art Car Festival, Thin Line Fest,  and multiple Pride celebrations, while continuously advocating for LGBTQIA rights at the Texas State Capitol and beyond. Now, with his forthcoming sophomore album Delirium, De Casper enters a new creative chapter — darker, dirtier, dance-driven, and poised for a breakthrough.

His 2022 debut LP Femme Boy expanded his sonic world, weaving dancefloor heat, cinematic drama, and queer storytelling into a record that was equal parts brooding and explosive. That same year, the City of Austin proclaimed Caleb De Casper Day, recognizing his cultural impact. He went on to perform yearly at SXSW, Austin City Limits Music Festival, Utopia Fest, Houston’s Art Car Festival, Thin Line Fest,  and multiple Pride celebrations, while continuously advocating for LGBTQIA rights at the Texas State Capitol and beyond. name: Grace Sorensen

contributors.name: Grace Sorensen
contributors.artist_connection: Label Management, Brand Partnership, Other Artists to Tour With, Booking Agent - US, Booking Agent - UK/Europe, Booking Agent - Worldwide, PR/Publicity Agency, Publishing, Sync/Music Supervisors
contributors.details: Grace Sorensen is one of the fastest independent-rising stars in the music scene. As a multi-hyphenate singer, songwriter, and dancer, she’s been dubbed "Austin's Wonderkid" and “Austin’s R&B Cool Girl” by the Austin Chronicle and KUTX. In her young career she has already been featured on Joe Budden’s “Sleeper Picks,” collaborated with BLK ODYSSY, been inducted to the Recording Academy's Class of 2025, played Austin City Limits Festival, SXSW Austin & London, and surpassed one million organic streams on her single "Digits.” She debuted her versatile album "BLUEPRINT" February 2025 and has exciting expectation of new collaborations, visual projects, and records.

name: grima

contributors.name: grima
contributors.artist_connection: Label Management, Distribution - Worldwide, Other Artists to Tour With, Booking Agent - Worldwide
contributors.details:
Reverby guitars and post-punk energy meet dreamy Spanish
vocals – somewhere between future anxiety and the desire for
self-realization.
German-Spanish artist grima emerged on Cologne’s wave scene in
2024, leaning into a '90s-inspired shoegaze sound that now defines
both his live shows and debut EP.
Early single En busca de caught international attention – including
airplay by London DJ and musician Nabihah Iqbal on her BBC Radio
6 show. Following his live debut in Berlin, grima played international
showcases in spring 2025, including Liverpool Sound City (UK) and
c/o pop Festival (DE).
His debut EP instantes (antes de caer) was released in July 2025,
accompanied by a sold-out release show in his adopted hometown
Cologne. The EP was featured on several Spotify Editorial Playlists
and even landed the cover of Fresh Finds Spain.
Recent highlights include a support slot for acclaimed American
shoegaze band glare and three shows at Reeperbahn Festival
2025 – all while grima is already working on new material.

long_description:
Join us for the Startup Germany Night, the central meeting point for Germany’s startup scene and its global partners in Austin. After a productive day at SXSW, we invite you to unwind in a sophisticated yet relaxed atmosphere. Connect with founders, investors, and ecosystem builders from both sides of the Atlantic. Discover the bold ideas driving the next wave of innovation while enjoying first-class DJ sets and a premium selection of drinks. Experience firsthand why Germany remains a world-class launchpad for scalable solutions and lasting partnerships.

name: Beyond The Duplex Planet

contributors.name: Beth Harrington
contributors.details: Beth Harrington is an Emmy-winning Grammy-nominated indie filmmaker whose work explores American history, music and culture. Her films have premiered at scores of festivals here and abroad including multiple times at SXSW. She’s also worked with public television stations WGBH in Boston and OPB-Portland creating shows for local and national air.

events.subgenre: EducationSocial IssuesThe Arts/TheaterYouth/Teen
events.name: Dead Deer High

long_description: In 1979, David Greenberger, a recent art school grad became activities director at a Boston nursing home. David began interviewing the residents, rejecting pat questions with the unexpected: "Which do you prefer – coffee or meat?," “What is embarrassment?,” and “How close can you get to a penguin?” The result was The Duplex Planet, an early ‘zine characterized by humor, warmth and sincerity. Today David’s work takes the form of spoken word shows and recordings. Beyond the Duplex Planet explores notions of aging and its intersection with art and community. It’s also a slightly ironic look at the life of an artist devoted to documenting the elderly who is himself in his senior years.

films.logline: In 1979, artist David Greenberger's talks with senior citizens become a word-of-mouth hit 'zine, "The Duplex Planet." Four decades on, now a senior himself, he has much to tell us about the nature of art, conversation and growing old.

name: Jessie Chambers

contributors.name: Jessie Chambers
contributors.artist_connection: Label Management, Brand Partnership, Other Artists to Tour With, Booking Agent - US, PR/Publicity Agency, Publishing, Sync/Music Supervisors
contributors.details:
Jessie Chambers is an independent singer-songwriter crafting timeless pop with a glam-rock edge. Her effortless, unmistakable voice delivers songs that are both deeply personal and irresistibly catchy. After featuring on Nurko & Last Heroes’ “Promise Me,” Chambers broke through with singles like “Guess U Suck” (850K+ streams) and “Fever Dream,” which landed on Spotify’s Fresh Finds Pop.
In 2025, she was featured on Algorhythm by Los Wizzards, a project nominated for a 2026 Grammy Award, marking a career milestone and highlighting her versatility as an artist and collaborator. Her music will also be featured in the upcoming short film Lake St. Claire, written & directed by Caitlin Meyernik, expanding her work into film and visual storytelling.
Her single “Fall Right Back” made waves across streaming and social media and was highlighted by Women in Music as one of their Top Songs of 2025. Chambers’ performances have taken her from The Troubadour to Revolution Live, opening for Saint Motel, appearing in respected showcases nationwide, and making her SXSW debut this year. With new music on the way, Jessie Chambers continues to carve a singular path through today’s indie-pop landscape.

name: Sam LLanes

contributors.name: Sam LLanes
contributors.artist_connection: Brand Partnership, Gear Endorsement, Distribution - US, Other Artists to Tour With, Booking Agent - US
contributors.details:
Sam Llanes is a Christian Hip Hop artist with a message rooted in hope, love, and faith. Blending CHH with heartfelt storytelling, Sam brings a fresh sound with a timeless purpose. His music speaks to the ones who feel forgotten, the youth searching for direction, and anyone needing a reminder that God still moves.

From the stage to youth groups, and through his work with 4KIDS and the Youth Group Tour, Sam lives what he raps. Every lyric is a reflection of his journey—a husband, a father, a worship leader, and a man who found purpose through Jesus.

For the overlooked. For the outcast. For every kid. This is Sam Llanes.

Love God Love People Change The World

name: Saint Harison

contributors.name: Saint Harison
contributors.details: Bio: Saint Harison is a rising artist with an undeniable voice from Southampton, United Kingdom. He currently lives in Los Angeles, CA. Having quickly risen to Internet fame from public support from SZA and Jazmine Sullivan to Justin Bieber, Timbaland and Elton John, he’s one of the latest artists to watch. Citing Amy Winehouse and Frank Ocean as two key musical influences, Saint has been covered by Rolling Stone, British Vogue, Wonderland, etc. and was named Apple Music's global Up Next artist. He made his late night TV debut on Jimmy Kimmel Live! after his viral COLORS performance of “ego talkin,” which sparked the viral #egotalkinchallenge on TikTok. His 7-track EP lost a friend was released in 2023 and has amassed over 200M cumulative streams, continuing to grow. He returned in fall 2025 with his single "ghosted," and recently released his latest single "bad," produced by Grammy-winning producer duo NovaWav (Beyoncé, JAY-Z, Jazmine Sullivan, etc.). He's gearing up to release his highly anticipated project this year.

name: Next of Kin

contributors.name: Next of Kin
contributors.details:
In March of 2023, Lili Hickman, Caelin Tralongo and Madison Baker,  didn't realize what awaited them on the other end of a rough mix. After a single listen, what began as a collaboration on Jekyll & Hyde transformed into a full album and the budding of new band. Some may call it fate, others pure luck, but they call it Next of Kin.
With a sound that blends country-tinged soundscapes, marked by rich three-part harmonies and honest storytelling, it's hard for any listener in any room not to be moved by this cult country trio currently taking Austin, TX by the horns-one venue at a time.

name: I See Orange

contributors.name: I See Orange
contributors.details:
We are a Mexican lead British 3-piece alternative post-grunge rock band. Starting in early 2022, our lead singer moved from Mexico to the UK. The band formed after an impromptu rehearsal session and discovering the chemistry we had playing together we quickly got to work. Writing, playing gigs and recording, releasing our first single in that same year, shortly followed by our debut EP Lonesome Joy. We are now about to release our debut Album with the first few singles already out and their music videos on YouTube hitting almost half a million views. 
Hailing from Mexico, Giselle brought to the UK her unique taste and a talent for writing folk pop, looking to explore a new musical direction fuelled by a passion for rock. Finding Cameron and Charlie, two British born and raised musicians marked the inception of I See Orange, mixing multiple genres into their unique post-grunge sound, a deliberate combo of captivating melodies, clever lyricism and heavy rock.
Bringing raw energy, heavy riffs and powerful melodic vocals to every stage we hit. We blend the gritty, nostalgic sound of the 90's with our own unique twist.

name: Pierce Washington

contributors.name: Pierce Washington
contributors.artist_connection: Brand Partnership, Gear Endorsement, Booking Agent - Worldwide, PR/Publicity Agency, Sync/Music Supervisors
contributors.details: Pierce Washington is an award-winning hip-hop artist from Dallas, Texas, whose sound bridges jazz influences, live instrumentation, and modern production — creating music that feels both timeless and forward-thinking. Known for his cinematic storytelling and commanding stage presence, Pierce has emerged as one of the leading voices in Dallas hip-hop. His collaborations with legendary producer Madlib and rap icon Lil Wayne showcase his versatility and creative range. Fresh off headlining The Proof of Concept and Folktales tours, Pierce continues to push artistic boundaries through his innovative approach to music, visuals, and brand artistry.

name: Astralorp

contributors.name: Astralorp
contributors.details: They define themselves “Discomatica”: an electric guitar that becomes a synthesizer, were a classic arpeggio moves bass and melody in a flowing counterpoint as if it were three instruments in one, and a drumbeat that flows between disco, dance, math-rock and alternative, all with a video game feel. Everything is recorded live! An electronic DJ set played with feet and fingers by guitarist Andrea Faccioli (already with Vasco Brondi, Le Luci Della Centrale Elettrica, Baustelle, Cisco), and drummer Niccolò Fornabaio (already with Vasco Brondi, Le Luci Della Centrale Elettrica, Vinicio Capossela, Marlene Kuntz).

name: Saige Davis

contributors.name: Saige Davis
contributors.artist_connection: Other Artists to Tour With, Booking Agent - US, Booking Agent - UK/Europe, Booking Agent - Worldwide, Producer/Studio Engineer, Publishing, Sync/Music Supervisors
contributors.details: Raised in a sunny southern California beach town, Saige Davis writes country-leaning songs straight from the heart with melodies that feel everlasting. Writing primarily on her own, she creates music that feels grounded and familiar - and yet wholly her own. Influenced by both the country classics and also Americana with a modern edge, her songs lean on acoustic guitars, simple arrangements, and lyrics that leave room to breathe. Whether written quietly at home or brought to life in the studio with producers Caleb Nelson (Mt. Joy) and Patrick Lyons (Colter Wall, Luke Grimes, Noeline Hoffman), Saige’s music shows a deep respect for timeless storytelling and feels imminent for a breakthrough in the year ahead.

name: Astrokeyy

contributors.name: Astrokeyy
contributors.artist_connection: Brand Partnership, Gear Endorsement, Distribution - US, Distribution - Worldwide, Other Artists to Tour With, Booking Agent - US, Booking Agent - UK/Europe, Booking Agent - Worldwide, Publishing, Sync/Music Supervisors
contributors.details:
Astrokeyy is a Houston-based hip-hop artist carving his own lane with sharp lyricism, atmospheric production, and a sound rooted in Southern culture with a forward-thinking edge. Known for his commanding live presence, Astrokeyy has been selected as an **official SXSW artist twice**, cementing his reputation as a standout performer on one of the world’s most influential stages.

He has shared stages with respected names in hip-hop including **Rome Streetz, Jay Worthy, and Devin The Dude**, holding his own alongside both underground heavyweights and Southern legends. Recently, Astrokeyy released his latest project "Southern Hospitality" fully produced by Marc Spano and executive produced by Dough Networkz a cohesive body of work that highlights his growth, Southern identity, and refined sonic vision.

Blending raw storytelling, confident delivery, and hypnotic beats, Astrokeyy represents the grind, ambition, and creativity of Houston’s new generation. With momentum fueled by high-profile performances and a focused artistic direction, he continues pushing his sound forward with longevity, authenticity, and impact in mind.

name: Lew Apollo

contributors.name: Lew Apollo
contributors.details:
Lew Apollo is a rising force in modern soul, captivating audiences with his soul-stirring melodies and poignant songwriting. KUTX praised him as “the perfect summer vibe,” a fitting description for an artist whose music blends hypnotic guitar, cinematic production, and a sultry, smoky voice into lush, resonant soundscapes. Originally hailing from rural Barnum, MN, Lew’s artistry is deeply rooted in his home state’s heritage, fusing the legacies of Bob Dylan and Prince with modern influences like Hozier, Leon Bridges, and Labrinth.
The tragic loss of his father in 2022 profoundly shaped Lew’s songwriting, catalyzing a body of work that confronts themes of grief, isolation, and resilience while offering hope and connection. His debut EP JUNGLE, produced by BLK ODYSSY, introduced him as a bold new voice and fueled a run of sold-out shows at iconic Austin venues like The Pershing and Antone’s.
Since then, Lew has taken his music to wider audiences, touring in support of Los Lonely Boys and earning airplay on KUTX with his single “Diamonds and Gold” as well as “Let the Light In” from his debut album. Self-produced from start to finish, Fool’s Gold has already surpassed 300,000 streams in under two months and is creating buzz for its fearless vulnerability and lush production. Press outlets have echoed the excitement: AMP Music declared “Lew Apollo will be a force in the R&B and pop stratospheres. Be warned,” while Earmilk praised how “Apollo’s signature smoky voice sets the tone for a sultry soundscape.” With his clear vision and unwavering dedication to using music as a vessel for healing, Lew Apollo is quickly emerging as one of the most exciting new voices to watch in soul.

The tragic loss of his father in 2022 profoundly shaped Lew’s songwriting, catalyzing a body of work that confronts themes of grief, isolation, and resilience while offering hope and connection. His debut EP JUNGLE, produced by BLK ODYSSY, introduced him as a bold new voice and fueled a run of sold-out shows at iconic Austin venues like The Pershing and Antone’s.
Since then, Lew has taken his music to wider audiences, touring in support of Los Lonely Boys and earning airplay on KUTX with his single “Diamonds and Gold” as well as “Let the Light In” from his debut album. Self-produced from start to finish, Fool’s Gold has already surpassed 300,000 streams in under two months and is creating buzz for its fearless vulnerability and lush production. Press outlets have echoed the excitement: AMP Music declared “Lew Apollo will be a force in the R&B and pop stratospheres. Be warned,” while Earmilk praised how “Apollo’s signature smoky voice sets the tone for a sultry soundscape.” With his clear vision and unwavering dedication to using music as a vessel for healing, Lew Apollo is quickly emerging as one of the most exciting new voices to watch in soul.

name: Tipa Tipo

contributors.details: Tipa Tipo fuses '70s soft rock and disco with Latin rhythms to create their fresh take on tropical yacht rock en español. Fronted by co-producers Adele Fournet and Felipe Wurst, with Jordan Auber on drums and percussion.

name: Mission

contributors.name: Mission
contributors.artist_connection: Brand Partnership, Gear Endorsement, Booking Agent - US
contributors.details: Born in Greenville, Mississippi, and raised in Sacramento, California, Antonio Smith, better known as Mission, is a genre-defying Christian music artist who has dedicated his life and music to glorifying God. As a husband to Shawnay Smith and father of four—two boys and two girls—Mission’s journey of faith began when he gave his life to Christ at the age of 18, and his music continues to reflect that commitment. Mission’s life and music are deeply rooted in Matthew 6:33: “Seek first the kingdom of God and His righteousness, and all these things will be added to you.” He believes in doing God’s will, not his own, and encourages others to love God’s people. His personal motto, “All of You, none of me,” is based on the scripture “I must decrease so the Lord can increase,” signifying his desire for God’s will to be done in his life above all else.

name: Danxgerous

contributors.name: Danxgerous
contributors.details:
Danxgerous – the solo project of Daniela “Dan” Mariti – is born from the meeting of Italian and Czech roots and a musical heritage steeped in singing and instruments. A singer-songwriter and multi-instrumentalist, Danxgerous crafts a sonic universe suspended between indie-rock, dreamy pop, and contemporary indie-folk, where light and melancholy intertwine to create deep and captivating emotional landscapes.
After studying music theory and harmony at Saint Louis in Rome and performing with the band In June, Danxgerous debuted as a solo artist in 2023 with the independent label We Were Never Being Boring (WWNBB), releasing the singles Keys, Sides, Cold Yet Dazzling, and Venom. In 2024, she brought the project to international stages, with a standout moment at SXSW 2024 in Austin, Texas, performing four shows including the prestigious International Day Stage, marking a pivotal step in her career and expanding her international audience.
2025 is dedicated to writing, recording, and producing her debut album “Old Soul” — a journey into the universe of an old soul navigating the modern world, exploring mystical dreams, introspection, and the beauty of nature.

name: Dallas Tetnus

contributors.name: Dallas Tetnus
contributors.artist_connection: Brand Partnership, Gear Endorsement, Distribution - US, Other Artists to Tour With, Booking Agent - US, PR/Publicity Agency, Publishing, Sync/Music Supervisors
contributors.details:
Dallas Tenus is a four piece rock band from Raleigh, North Carolina that formed in 2022 and includes a collective of members who have traveled the world playing and performing music.  The four established band members - Greg Clayton (Rhythm guitar and vocals), Billy Alphin (drums), Danny Kurtz (lead guitar) and David Wright (bass guitar) - have collectively played in various major label and national touring bands through the years including Whiskeytown, AntiSeen, Drivin’ n Cryin', Flat Duo Jets, Squirrel Nut Zippers, The Backsliders, Sarah Shook, Lustre, and The Rosebuds (to name a few).  The new collective that is Dallas Tetnus is a musical combination of all of these influences, with a stage show that is packed with static energy and a pure rock showmanship that is one to be seen.

The band plays loud, short, catchy, 70s - inspired tunes with influences from The Ramones, The Stooges, and KISS. Their unique and original stage presence is hard to forget. Their shows have plenty of visual appeal and engagement with smoke and bubbles rolling through every set, with white suits and a pink lit backdrop to boot.  

The debut album, Welcome To Dallas Tetnus, is available everywhere now.

contributors.artist_connection: Distribution - US, Distribution - Worldwide, Booking Agent - US
contributors.details: Boooka is an Austin-based hip-hop artist, curator, and creative director known for blending sharp lyricism with intentional storytelling. As the founder of SUMN2SAY, he has built a platform dedicated to spotlighting independent artists and cultivating real community through live experiences. With the release of his 2026 album BTS, Boooka continues to push his sound forward—balancing introspection, ambition, and culture while creating opportunities both on and off the stage.

name: OKAN

contributors.name: OKAN
contributors.artist_connection: Brand Partnership, Other Artists to Tour With, Booking Agent - US, Booking Agent - Worldwide, PR/Publicity Agency, Publishing
contributors.details:
Taking their name from the word for “heart” in the Afro-Cuban religion of Santería, the duo OKAN creates an alchemy of Cuban rhythms and chants with high-octane indie jazz and pop. Singing in Spanish, Yoruba, and Spanglish, OKAN explores resistance, rebirth, and joy — forging rhythm and harmony through acts of survival, both personal and cultural.

Following their Juno Award–winning album Okantomi — performed on NPR’s Tiny Desk and toured internationally while supporting Grammy-winning duo Rodrigo y Gabriela — OKAN’s upcoming fall release "Ife Ira" features a collaboration with Daymé Arocena.

OKAN is led by violinist and vocalist Elizabeth Rodríguez and percussionist and vocalist Magdelys Savigne — both Grammy and Latin Grammy nominees — whose powerful harmonies and fearless musicianship have earned the duo a global following.

name: Parris Chariz

contributors.name: Parris Chariz
contributors.artist_connection: Brand Partnership, Gear Endorsement, Publishing, Sync/Music Supervisors
contributors.details: "A Detroit native, on the rise with a mission to bridge the gap between faith-based platforms and mainstream music. Parris Chariz, short for charismatic, is an edgy, yet vibrant artist with a trap sound. Parris experienced numerous downfalls throughout his life but those valleys lead him to music. His debut album “2045” gained the attention of tastemakers within the CHH and mainstream Hip-Hop community. From being listed on Rapzilla’s Freshman in 2016 List to headlining a nationwide tour along with Ty Brasel, WHATUPRG, & Aaron Cole. Parris has made his mark within the Hip-Hop community that is extremely unique and far from the rest. His music has encouraged his listeners to know what’s real and to be true to yourself through every obstable this life brings us. His recently released album “Take You To Parris” has set a standard of authentic creativity provided a voice to the unheard. Parris has made his mark as a creative and will continue to make music that speaks to the soul."

name: NOAMZ

contributors.name: NOAMZ
contributors.artist_connection: Label Management, Brand Partnership, Gear Endorsement, Booking Agent - US, Sync/Music Supervisors
contributors.details:
NOAMZ is a flutist, vocalist, multi-instrumentalist, and producer making alt soul music. She was raised in a small town in Wisconsin by a Guadeloupean mother and French father.

She went on tour in 2024 on her artist project, released her EP “Personne” August of 2025 with Guesthouse, and plays regularly across SoCal and the Midwest. And has recently grown in popularity online for her flute beatboxing. 

Featured on numerous LA based artist tracks, radios, and the Senegalese soccer anthem, she plans to release three musical projects this coming year, from her meditative flute project “Retrouvaille” to her soulful Melodic DnB EP “TEXTURES” dropping this March.
